revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{good article}} {{Infobox person |name = Howard B Sims Sr. ( Sandman Sims ) |image = Howard-Sandman-Sims-&-his-sand-box.jpg |caption = Sims dancing in his signature sandbox |birth_date = {{birth date|1917|1|24}} |birth_place = [[Fort Smith, Arkansas]] |occupation = [[tap dance]]r |death_date = {{death date and age|2003|5|20|1917|1|24}} |death_place = [[the Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]]{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3iYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA142|title=ya heard?: Who Did What Where & When|author=Zado-Wasfie, Giselle|work=[[VIBE]]|page=142|date=September 2003}} |spouse = Solange A. Sims, 1959–2003 (his death) |children = Diane Sims-Jones
Howard B Sims Jr. }} '''Howard "Sandman" Sims''' (January 24, 1917 – May 20, 2003) was an [[African-American]] [[tap dance]]r who began his career in [[vaudeville]]. He was skilled in a style of dancing that he performed in a wooden sandbox of his own construction, and acquired his nickname from the sand he sprinkled to alter and amplify the sound of his dance steps. "They called the board my [[Stradivarius]]," Sims said of his sandbox. From the 1950s to the year 2000, Sims was a regular attraction—a "fixture"{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v7UDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq=%22sandman+sims%22|title=Tap Legend Howard 'Sandman' Sims Succumbs|work=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]]|date=June 23, 2003}}—at [[Harlem]]'s noted [[Apollo Theater]], comedically ushering failed acts offstage with a hook, broom or other prop. He was also involved in New York City's [[Hoofers Club]], a venue primarily for black tap dancers. As part of the resurgence of interest in tap dancing in the 1980s, Sandman Sims served as a cultural ambassador, representing the United States with dance performances around the world. He was featured in the 1989 dance film ''[[Tap (film)|Tap]]'', along with [[Sammy Davis Jr.]], [[Gregory Hines]] and [[Savion Glover]], demonstrating classic challenge dancing. Sims also appeared in a 1990 episode of ''[[The Cosby Show]]'' as Rudy's tap dancing teacher, facing off against Cliff ([[Bill Cosby]]) in a good-natured tap challenge. In her review of the play based on his life, ''[[New York Times]]'' critic [[Anna Kisselgoff]] wrote, "Sims is a virtuoso among virtuosos—in a class by himself. To say Mr. Sims dances on sand is like saying [[Philippe Petit]] is a tightrope walker."{{cite news|author=Kisselgoff, Anna|title=Dance: Play Based on Sandman Sims|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 2, 1986|page=C29|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/07/02/arts/dance-play-based-on-sandman-sims.html|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} == Early life == Born in [[Fort Smith, Arkansas]] on January 24, 1917,{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2003/may/31/local/me-sims31|title=Howard 'Sandman' Sims, 86; Tap Dancer Famed for His Percussive Range|author=Segal, Lewis|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 31, 2003|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Howard+%22Sandman%22+Sims.-a0111979441|title=Howard 'Sandman' Sims|author=Goldberg, Jane|work=[[Dance Magazine]]|page=232|date=December 1, 2003|accessdate=September 5, 2015}} Sims was one of 12 children. The family soon relocated to [[Los Angeles, California]], where he was raised. Describing his childhood, Sims said, "It was just a whole big dancing family."{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F02EFDA133EE334BC4153DFBF66838C669EDE|title=This Sandman Will Keep Them Awake|author=Dunning, Jennifer|work=The New York Times|date=September 9, 1977|page=50|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}{{subscription needed}} He learned to dance from his father, and said he was dancing as soon as he could walk. He began tap-dancing at the age of 3. He attributed some of his early love for tap dancing in particular to his mother, exasperated that he kept wearing out the toes of his shoes, putting steel taps on the shoes. Along with his brothers, Sims was dancing on the sidewalks of Los Angeles from a young age. At the age of 14, peeping in the windows of a dance school got Sims arrested for loitering, but he was able to dance his way to freedom, convincing a judge that his reason for being on that street was legitimate.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-03-29/entertainment/8903300775_1_sandman-sims-national-tap-dance-day-four-step-brothers|title=Tapping Into A Trend|author=Campbell, Mary|date=March 29, 1989|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|agency=Associated Press|quote=I got put in jail," Sims said. "I had to go to court to get loose. This is a true story. I told the judge I wasn't loitering. I like to see how they dance because I try to be a [[buck dance]]r. He told them to clear the chairs and desks away and to let him see what I did. I danced a little bit and he said, 'Case dismissed!'|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} As a young man, despite his dance talent, Sims aspired to be not a professional dancer, but a professional [[boxing|boxer]]. After twice breaking his hand, he decided he needed a different means of making a living.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-07-04/entertainment/ca-690_1_rhythm-essence-taps|title=Best Feet Forward In 'Essence Of Rhythm'|author=Pasles, Chris|work=Los Angeles Times|date=July 4, 1986|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} Sims had noticed that boxing audiences reacted positively to the way he would dance in the [[rosin]] box before getting into the ring, and especially to the distinctive sound his dancing made moving the rosin granules around the wooden box. He began to consider dancing as a career alternative. Sims experimented with several different methods of reproducing the rosin box effect, gluing sandpaper to either his shoes or his dancing mat, but the sandpaper created too much wear on the other surface. Finally he found the solution: loose sand in a low-lipped box. "People went for the scraping sound ... So I made a sound board by sprinkling sand on a flat platform. That was in 1935." His sandbox remained his trademark throughout his career, with some venues even telling Sims, "If you don't bring your sandbox, don't come at all."{{cite journal|url=http://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/onlinessays/JC26folder/NoMapsonTaps.html |title=''No Maps on My Taps:'' Forgotten dancers|author=Biederman, Marcia|journal=Jump Cut: A Review of Contemporary Media|volume=no. 26|pages=3–4|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} During this period, it was common for dancers to carry tap shoes with them and, when they encountered another dancer on the street, throw down their shoes by way of challenge. The culture of street dancing in the 1920s has been compared to the rise of [[break dancing]] six decades later. As the journal ''[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]]'' described it, "'challenge dancing,' in which each performer tries to outdo the other, is part of tap dancing's heritage, something like the [[jazz]] solos in which musicians try to outshine one another." Sims later described how the atmosphere of these dance challenges was at least as much collegial as combative, and how dancers learned from one another in what became essentially "open air dance schools".{{cite book|title=Rethinking Dance History: A Reader|author=Carter, Alexandra|publisher=Routledge|page=133|year=2004|isbn=978-0-415-28747-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jYaMAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA133}} Despite performing at various [[vaudeville]] venues, Sims found neither fame nor success as a dancer in Los Angeles. In 1947, he tagged along on one of his professional-boxer friend [[Archie Moore]]'s cross-country drives, and settled in [[New York City]]. == Harlem == After arriving in [[Harlem]], Sims began performing on the street as he had done in California, but faced stiff competition from other innovative dancers: "I knew people who danced on dinner plates. ... There was a man who could dance on newspapers without tearing them. And another who constructed a gigantic xylophone to tap on." He performed on corners in between working whatever jobs he could find, and then discovered the "[[amateur night|Amateur Night]]" stage on Wednesdays at the [[Apollo Theater]], where he soon gained local notoriety. He eventually won the Amateur Night competition a record-breaking 25 times, after which a rule was instituted that performers could no longer compete once they had earned four first prizes.
When big name dancers played The Apollo, there was nothing in the audience but dancers with their shoes," said Sandman Sims. "Up in the balcony dancers, and the first six rows, you saw nothing but tap-dancers, want-to-be tap-dancers, gonna-be tap-dancers, tried-to-be tap-dancers. That's the reason a guy would want to dance at The Apollo.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yWJXUnPDFk0C&pg=PA99|title=Steppin' on the Blues: The Visible Rhythms of African American Dance|author=Malone, Jacqui|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=1996|page=99|isbn=978-0-252-06508-8}}
By the mid-1950s, he had been hired as the Apollo's stage manager, and soon began his role as the Apollo's famed "executioner", chasing Amateur Night contestants the crowd disapproved of off the stage{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wxa7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA485|title=Historical Dictionary of African American Television|author1=Fearn-Banks, Kathleen|author2=Burford-Johnson, Anne|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2005|pages=111, 230, 485|isbn=978-0-8108-5335-5}} with a [[shepherd's crook]]{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20563252,00.html|title=President Obama Sings Al Green's 'Let's Stay Together' |author=Silverman, Stephen M.|date=January 20, 2012|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} (known since vaudeville times as "the hook"){{cite book|chapter=Vaudeville & Burlesque History & Lingo|title=On the Midway|author=Keyser, Wayne|year=2008|publisher=Blue Ridge Entertainment |url=http://www.goodmagic.com/carny/vaud.htm|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} a broom,{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/30/arts/sandman-sims-86-tap-dancer-and-fixture-at-the-apollo.html|author=Martin, Douglas|title=Sandman Sims, 86, Tap Dancer and Fixture at the Apollo|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 30, 2003|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_uJPOpKE5e0C&pg=PT52&lpg=PT52&source=bl&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=%22sandman%20sims%22%20broom&f=false|title=Flip: The Inside Story of TV's First Black Superstar|author=Cook, Kevin|publisher=[[Plume (publisher)|Plume Books]] ([[Penguin Group]])|page=69|year=2013|isbn=978-0-14-218075-4}} or other props,{{cite web|url=https://www.apollotheater.org/history|title=Amateur Night History and Legacy|publisher=[[Apollo Theater]] official site|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} while dressed in a variety of wacky costumes, whether [[long underwear]], a clown suit, or even a diaper.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/style/1985/06/16/the-rebirth-of-the-boos/132dff0f-d675-4345-b668-bb299327d129/|title=The Rebirth of the Boos|author=Span, Paula|work=The Washington Post|date=June 16, 1985|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} Backstage, however, he would console defeated contestants with the story of his having been booed off ten times before he finally got to finish his own act. Sims would play "executioner" until shortly after [[Time Warner]] took over the Apollo{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2003/aug/07/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries|author=Monaghan, Terry|title=Sandman Sims: Bringing sand dancing back to Harlem|date=August 6, 2003|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=September 16, 2015}} in 1999.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/05/nyregion/rescue-time-at-the-apollo-time-warner-to-control-board.html|author1=Pristin, Terry|author2=Blumenthal, Ralph|title=Rescue Time at the Apollo: Time Warner to Control Board|work=The New York Times|page=|date=August 5, 1999|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} Having found work dancing did not stop him from dancing on the street, however. "If I saw a dancer, I'd challenge him. I didn't care who it was. The way to get known in New York was to be the best. That's what I strived to be." Part of the culture of street challenges, as in Los Angeles, was that competing dancers would also learn from one another. A significant change to Sims's dancing style came about as a result of his interaction with Harlem's [[hoofer]]s, practitioners of a variation on the tap he had learned on the west coast. Sims would later define the main difference between tap and hoofing as being that tap focuses on the heel and toe whereas hoofers "use the whole foot". As a result of the synergy between hoofing technique and his unique use of a sandbox, his routines were described as being "as rich in sounds and textures as they were in steps." Sims himself put it, "The feet are a set of drums." Constance Valis Hill, in her 2009 survey ''Tap Dancing America: A Cultural History'', described the hoofers' mecca thusly:
At the Hoofers Club, rookie and veteran, mostly [B]lack male tap dancers assembled to share with, steal from, and challenge each other; there, new standards were set for competition. These were nothing like the formalized [[buck dance|buck-dancing]] competitions of Tammany Hall, where judges sat beside, before, and beneath the stage to evaluate the [dancers'] clarity, speed, and presentation. The Hoofers Club comprised a more informal panel of peers, whose judgments could be cruel and mocking and were driven by an insistence on innovation. "Survive or die" was the credo. In an eccentric fusion of imitation and innovation, young dancers were forced to find their style and rhythmic voice. It was said that on the wall of the Hoofers Club was written: "Thou shalt not copy each other's steps — Exactly."{{cite book|title=Tap Dancing America: A Cultural History|author=Hill, Constance Valis|pages=87|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rU9dUaCsd94C&pg=PA249&lpg=PA249&source=bl&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=%22hoofers%20club%22&f=false|isbn=978-0-19-539082-7|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}
Though he frequently took opportunities to explain the difference between tap and hoofing to the press in later years, and tended to refer to himself as a hoofer rather than a tap dancer, Sims did practice both forms of dance. In 1949, motivated by the death of [[Bill "Bojangles" Robinson]], Sims became a founding member of the [[Original Copasetics]], another fellowship of tap dancers that became a source of mentor-student relationships and would help bring about the revival of tap in the 1970s and 1980s.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/25/arts/dance/25brown.html|title=Ernest Brown, Last Member of the Original Tapping Copasetics, Dies at 93|author=Dunning, Jennifer|date=August 25, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} == Decline and revival of tap == Tap dancing lost popularity with audiences beginning in the late 1940s. A number of causes factored into this decline, among them the going out of style of vaudeville-style variety shows; a new tax that forced many ballrooms to close and thus closed venues to the big bands with whom tap dancers had used to perform; trends in music that favored smaller, more intimate groups of performers; and concomitant increases in interest among audiences in watching formal modern dance and ballet performances. Sims was quoted as having said of the period that "[t]ap didn't die ... It was just neglected."{{cite web|url=http://www.nypl.org/sites/default/files/TAPENCY2002cites.pdf|format=PDF|author=Hill, Constance Valis|title=Tap Dance in America: A Very Short History|year=2002|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} With paying gigs harder to find and paying less, Sims turned to other sources of income. Despite not having had any formal instruction himself,{{cite web|url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F04E3DD163AE334BC4C52DFBF66838C669EDE|author = McDonagh, Don|title = Dance: Taps Close Fete|work = The New York Times|date = September 14, 1977|page = 63|quote = Howard (Sandman) Sims, a specialist in the art who swore that he never took a lesson in his life...|accessdate = September 4, 2015}}{{subscription needed}} he taught dance, including to such later stars as [[Gregory Hines]] and [[Ben Vereen]]. He also taught footwork to boxing greats [[Sugar Ray Robinson]] and [[Muhammad Ali]]. Less glamorously, he ran a café, and even worked as a carpenter and a mechanic. Despite the lean times for hoofers, Sims was always able to put food on the table for his family, having married in 1959. The late 1960s brought the beginning of a wave of nostalgia for tap, and Sims found his dance skills in demand again. In 1969, he was part of the all-star cast of ''Tap Happening'', a [[revue]] that played [[Off-Broadway]].{{cite book|title=Before, Between, and Beyond: Three Decades of Dance Writing|author=Banes, Sally|page=79|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-299-22154-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P2xLfSJTTCcC&pg=PA79}}{{cite book|title=Tap Dancing America: A Cultural History|author=Hill, Constance Valis|pages=212–214|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rU9dUaCsd94C&pg=PA212|isbn=978-0-19-539082-7}} ''Tap Happening'' was popular enough to run for several years.{{cite web|url=http://biography.jrank.org/pages/2431/Sims-Howard-Sandman.html|title=Howard 'Sandman' Sims Biography — Developed Unique Dance Style, Rediscovered by Tap Aficionados, Cited as an Innovator, Selected works|author=Edelman, Rob|work=Brief Biographies|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} The [[crescendo]] of interest in tap dancing continued, and in 1972, Sims danced in the production ''Best of the Hoofers'' at the [[Orpheum Theatre (Manhattan)|Orpheum Theatre]].{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=980CE7DE1F3EE63BBC4953DFB0668389669EDE|title=Tap Show Propels Fans and Dancers; 'Best of the Hoofers' Brings Old Spirit to Orpheum|author=Kisselgoff, Anna|work=The New York Times|page=50|date=June 1, 1972|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}{{subscription needed}} "Hoofing is not a dying art form," he asserted in 1977, and subsequent events would prove him right. 1979 saw the release of ''[[No Maps on My Taps]]'', which featured Sims facing off against fellow tap stars [[Chuck Green]]—who had served as Sims's mentor during his early years in New York—and [[Bunny Briggs]], in a three-way dance challenge. The documentary also reunited him with bandleader [[Lionel Hampton]], whom he had toured with in years past. In 1980, a far cry from the tiny venues he had been lucky to play just a few years earlier, Sims performed before a crowd of 2,600 fans at the [[Lincoln Center]] during the [[Newport Jazz Festival]].{{cite book|title=Tap Dancing America: A Cultural History|author=Hill, Constance Valis|pages=249–250|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2009 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rU9dUaCsd94C&pg=PA249|isbn=978-0-19-539082-7}} Later that year, Sims was one of the instructor-performers of the ''By Word of Foot'' "teach-in" series, spending a week demonstrating his hoofing techniques for a new generation of tap enthusiasts. As part of New York's leg of the 1981 Newport Jazz Festival (which spanned both NYC and its home city of [[Newport, Rhode Island]], that year), he performed with former [[Cotton Club]] bandleader [[Cab Calloway]] in a production called ''Stompin' at the Savoy''.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/arts/jazz-events.html|title=Jazz Events|work=The New York Times|date=June 27, 1981|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} A few weeks later, Sims was on stage at the [[American Dance Festival]], dancing both with and without his sandbox.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/19/arts/dance-festival-looks-at-vaudeville.html|title=Dance: Festival Looks at Vaudeville|author=Anderson, Jack|work=The New York Times|date=July 19, 1981|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} By 1982, Sims was part of a promotional tour reviving interest in ''No Maps on My Taps'' with co-stars Bunny Briggs and Chuck Green, their pre-screening performances backed by Cab Calloway.{{cite book|title=Tap Dancing America: A Cultural History|author=Hill, Constance Valis|page=282|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2009 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rU9dUaCsd94C&pg=PA212&lpg=PA212&source=bl#v=onepage&q=%22tap%20happening%22%20sandman%20sims&f=false|isbn=978-0-19-539082-7}} Even as booked performances were coming more regularly, Sims never stopped participating in street-corner challenges, encouraging younger generations of dancers and inviting them to learn his moves. The [[National Endowment for the Arts]] granted Sims a $5,000 National Heritage Fellowship in 1984.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2003/scene/people-news/howard-sandman-sims-1117887335/|title=Howard 'Sandman' Sims: Dancer, Apollo Theater stage manager|date=June 3, 2003|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} "I thought I was making noise all these years," Sims said of the award. "Now they're calling it culture." He used the funds to teach dance to children in Harlem, using a parking lot in lieu of a formal dance studio, drawing on his own youth learning dance on the street. Sims would later explain, "most people wait [to study dance] until after they've grown up—and then it's too late." That same year, [[clogging|clogger]] [[Ira Bernstein]] received an NEA Folk Arts Apprenticeship grant "[t]o study traditional [B]lack tap dance with master dancer Howard 'Sandman' Sims."{{cite web|url=http://arts.gov/sites/default/files/NEA-Annual-Report-1984.pdf|format=PDF|title=Annual Report 1984|publisher=National Endowment for the Arts official site|page=67|editor=Bowersox, Joan|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} Sims loved to teach; his son recounted how Sandman would "stop every kid he saw and show them a step and get them to copy a step. He enjoyed that more than performing in front of an audience."{{cite web|url=http://www.princetoninfo.com/index.php/component/us1more/?key=11-19-2008%20Hoofer|title=The Legacy of a Harlem Hoofer|author=Fox, Barbara Figge|work=[[U.S. 1 (newspaper)|U.S. 1]]|date=November 19, 2008|accessdate=September 5, 2015}} === The Apollo reopens === Meanwhile, Harlem's Apollo Theater, where Sims had served for years as Amateur Night's "executioner", had been closed for most of a decade.{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/1986-02-19/entertainment/26086876_1_apollo-theater-security-guard-amateur-night|title=Joy And Tears At The Apollo|author=Logan, Joe|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=February 19, 1986|accessdate=September 3, 2015|quote=Sims had danced on stage, giving an act its cue to leave.}} Then, following an extensive renovation, the venue reopened in 1985, bringing increased attention to both the Apollo and his role there. "I'm their protector, not the executioner," he explained to ''[[The Washington Post]]''. "Because that audience can get really hostile." Sims described seeing displeased audiences throw bottles and even horseshoes at performers who he did not hustle off stage fast enough.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/18/nyregion/column-one-about-new-york-amateurs-on-stage-semiamateur-critics.html|title=Amateurs on Stage, Semiamateur Critics|author=Geist, William E.|work=The New York Times|date=February 18, 1987|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} When ''[[The New York Times]]'' interviewed him about his "executioner" role, he said of the acts that got booed off, "I tell them to work on their act and come back," encouraging them to try again. In 1986, Sims starred in ''The Tap Tradition'' at [[Symphony Space]] New York (which also hosted a showing of ''No Maps on My Taps''), earning a rave review from ''The New York Times''.{{cite web|author=Anderson, Jack|title=The Dance: Sandman Sims on Tap|date=March 2, 1986|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/02/arts/the-dance-sandman-sims-on-tap.html|page=64|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} He also made a brief appearance in a play based on his life, ''The Sand Dancer'', which was written by poet Sandra Hochman and starred [[LeLand Gantt]], and which received another rave review: "Sims is a virtuoso among virtuosos—in a class by himself. To say Mr. Sims dances on sand is like saying [[Philippe Petit]] is a tightrope walker." And he traveled to Los Angeles to perform in a production called ''Essence of Rhythm'' with fellow tap stars including [[Charles Coles|Charles "Honi" Coles]] and [[Jimmy Slyde]]. Sandman Sims was the guest star of ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' on May 14, 1987.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/late-night-with-david-letterman/show-0858-870514-178083/|title= Late Night With David Letterman – Season 6 – Episode 40 — Show #0858 (870514)|website=TV.com|accessdate=September 5, 2015}} ''[[It's Showtime at the Apollo]]'', a TV broadcast of the Apollo Theater's Amateur Night performances, began broadcasting in September 1987 on [[NBC]] stations, bringing awareness of Sims's "executioner" role to a wider audience.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/showtime-at-the-apollo/|title=Showtime at the Apollo: Show Summary|website=TV.com|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} A particularly busy year, 1988 saw Sims tour the world as a cultural ambassador on behalf of the U.S. State Department, traveling to over 50 countries in a span of 11 months. By 1989, Sims's popularity was at an all-time high, and he told the Associated Press, "I can't fulfill all the work they give me. ... I can't walk out on the street without somebody showing me a time step." Tap dancing's popularity was nearing a new peak as well, with three major American cities ([[Houston, Texas]]; [[Portland, Oregon]]; [[Washington, D.C.]]) hosting tap-dance festivals. In movie theaters, the dance drama ''[[Tap (film)|Tap]]'' was introducing Sims's footwork (and that of his former student Gregory Hines) to audiences who had never had the opportunity to see him perform before.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/02/10/movies/review-film-tapping-and-strutting-into-a-whirl-of-romance.html|title=Review/Film; Tapping and Strutting Into a Whirl of Romance|author=Canby, Vincent|work=The New York Times|date=February 10, 1989|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} Playing a thinly-fictionalized version of himself named "Mr. Sims", Sims made a 1990 appearance on ''[[The Cosby Show]]'', then one of the most popular programs on television.{{cite web|url=http://www.classictvhits.com/tvratings/1989.htm |title=TV Ratings: 1989–1990|work=ClassicTVHits.com |accessdate=September 2, 2015}} "Mr. Sims" was the dance instructor the Huxtables signed their young daughter Rudy up with in order to help her prepare for a class assignment about the [[Harlem Renaissance]]. During the episode, Cliff Huxtable ([[Bill Cosby]]) challenged "Mr. Sims" to a dance-off, part tribute to and part parody of Sims's real-life tap challenges, which Sims won handily.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/the-cosby-show/mr-sandman-12883/|title=The Cosby Show – Season – 6 – Episode 19 — Mr. Sandman|website=TV.com|accessdate=September 2, 2015}} Later that same year, the Apollo Theater played host to Rat-a-Tat-Tap, another tap-dance festival, and the Sandman, "always a deserved audience favorite at tap festivals," was a featured performer there alongside his ''Tap'' co-stars [[Savion Glover]] and [[Gregory Hines]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/arts/review-dance-feet-bringers-of-thunder-rat-a-tat-tap-at-apollo.html|title=Feet, Bringers of Thunder: Rat-a-Tat-Tap at Apollo|author=Anderson, Jack|work=The New York Times|date=July 5, 1990|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} Sims was a featured performer at the third annual celebration of [[National Tap Dance Day]] on May 30, 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.nytap.org/1993.html|title=Tap Extravaganza '93|publisher=New York Committee to Celebrate [[National Tap Dance Day]] official site|accessdate=September 5, 2015}} In 1998, the New York Committee to Celebrate National Tap Dance Day and the Young People's Tap Conference honored Sandman Sims for his contributions to the art of hoofing.{{cite web|url=http://www.nytap.org/1998yptc.html|title=Hotcha-Razz-Ma-Tap Conference|publisher=New York Committee to Celebrate National Tap Dance Day official site|accessdate=September 5, 2015}} == In popular culture == Sandman Sims, particularly in his role as Apollo Theater executioner, has been referenced frequently in African-American culture. * While a cast member on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in the '90s, [[Chris Rock]] played recurring character Nat X, a [[Black Power movement|Black Power]] talk show host. Sometimes, when at the culmination of a tirade against a guest, Nat X would send "The Sandman" (played by [[Chris Farley]] in a clown suit) to sweep the guest off the stage.{{cite web|url=https://www.nbc.com/saturday-night-live/cast/chris-rock-14736/character/nat-x-66231|title=Nat X on "SNL"|author=Rock, Chris|accessdate=March 30, 2017}} * On April 5, 2000, he was invoked by [[Huey Freeman]] in the long-running comic strip ''[[The Boondocks (comic strip)|The Boondocks]]'', who responded to an ineptly-told joke by saying, "Where is Sandman Sims when you need him ..."{{cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/boondocks/2015/06/17|title=The Boondocks Comic Strip, June 17, 2015 on GoComics.com|author=McGruder, Aaron|work=The Boondocks|date=April 5, 2000|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} * Performance artist [[Holly Bass]], along with other dancers, put on another play about Sims's life at the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[American History Museum]] (which was then hosting an exhibit on the Apollo Theater) on July 10, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smithsonian-institution/weekend-events-korean-film-gullah-stories-and-remembering-howard-sandman-sims-34589/|title=Weekend Events: Korean Film, Gullah Stories and Remembering Howard 'Sandman' Sims|author=Rhodes, Jesse|work=Smithsonian magazine|date=July 9, 2010|accessdate=September 4, 2015}} * [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]], referring to his own performance singing on the Apollo Theater stage (albeit not on Amateur Night) the evening before his [[2012 State of the Union address]], said, "Sandman did not come out!"{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/44/post/obama-jokes-with-spike-lee-performs-al-green-song-at-new-york-city-fundraisers/2012/01/20/gIQAJ7YRDQ_blog.html|title=Obama jokes with Spike Lee, performs Al Green song at New York City fundraisers|author=Nakamura, David|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 20, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2015}} == Personal life == While Sims had a first marriage which produced his first child Diane Sims, he later married his second wife, Solange. They would have 1 son together, Howard Sims Jr., as well as 5 grandchildren and 1 great-grandchild. Particularly in later years, Sims sometimes claimed not to be certain of his birth year, at times saying it was "a matter of opinion." Asked by a fan how old he was, Sims once replied, "Any number can play." == Death == Sims died on May 20, 2003 in New York City. He had suffered from [[Alzheimer's disease]]. A memorial service for Sims was held May 28, 2003 at the Apollo Theater. == Filmography == * ''No Maps on My Taps'' (1979) – Himself{{cite web|url=http://arts.gov/honors/heritage/fellows/howard-sandman-sims|title=NEA National Heritage Fellowships: Howard 'Sandman' Sims|publisher=National Endowment for the Arts official site|accessdate=September 2, 2015}}{{cite book|title=Vaudeville Old and New: An Encyclopedia of Variety Performers in America (Volume 1)|author1=Cullen, Frank|author2=Hackman, Florence|author3=McNeilly, Donald|publisher=Routledge|year=2006|page=157|isbn=978-0-415-93853-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XFnfnKg6BcAC&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&source=bl&hl=en&sa=X#v=onepage&q=sandman%20sims&f=false|accessdate=September 16, 2015}} * ''Uptown: A Tribute to the Apollo Theatre'' (1980) – Himself{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/item/jots.200026303|title=Uptown: A Tribute to the Apollo Theatre|publisher=[[Library of Congress]] official site|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} * ''[[The Cotton Club (film)|The Cotton Club]]'' (1984) – Hoofer * ''Motown Returns to the Apollo'' (1985) – Himself{{cite * ''[[Kennedy Center Honors|The Kennedy Center Honors: A Celebration of the Performing Arts]]'' (1987) — Himself{{cite [[File:Lantern-Parade-10.jpg|thumb|right|''La Fête dé Noué'' in [[Jersey]].]] An '''illuminated procession''' is a [[procession]] held after dark so that lights carried by the participants form a spectacle. The lights will commonly be of the same type, so making a '''candlelight procession''', '''lantern parade''' or '''torchlight march'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Torch Light |url=https://www.amazon.com/J5-Tactical-V1-Pro-Flashlight-Original/dp/B00V7T1YRQ|accessdate=7 June 2013|author=Beverly N. White}}</ref>
Examples include the Christmas festival of [[Ndocciata]] in Italy; the Chinese [[Lantern Festival]] to celebrate the first full moon; and the [[Sanctuary of Our Lady of Lourdes#The Torchlight Procession|daily procession of pilgrims to the grotto of Lourdes]].
What is believed to be the largest and the best illuminated procession in the world is the [[Bridgwater Guy Fawkes Carnival]] held on the first Saturday of November in the town of Bridgwater, Somerset, in the UK. It is followed by a fireworks display that is unique to the town, known as squibbing. <ref>http://www.bridgwatercarnival.org.uk/</ref> The carnival parades also take place in a variety of Somerset towns throughout November.
==See also== *[[Candlelight vigil]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Pamela-1742.png|thumb|250px|right|A plate from the 1742 deluxe edition of [[Samuel Richardson]]'s ''[[Pamela, or, Virtue Rewarded]]''.]] '''Illustrated fiction''' is a hybrid narrative medium in which images and text work together to tell a story. It can take various forms, including fiction written for adults or children, magazine fiction, comic strips, and picture books.<ref name=Sillars>Sillars, Stuart, 1995, [https://books.google.com/books?id=hpjWh_Q-KJ8C&dq ''Visualisation in Popular Fiction, 1860-1960''], Routledge, {{ISBN|0-415-11914-6}}.</ref>
== Illustrated fiction in the 18th century == Apart from an occasional portrait or map, 18th century fiction was not usually illustrated, as publishers did not commission illustrations for new novels. In the novel ''[[The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling]]'', the author [[Henry Fielding]] refers to paintings by [[William Hogarth]] in order to explain what some of his characters look like.<ref name=Charlespg4>Cohen, Jane R., 1980, [https://books.google.com/books?id=2UhBswddDsEC ''Charles Dickens and His Original Illustrators''], Ohio State University Press, {{ISBN|0-8142-0284-5}}, page 4.</ref>
Illustrations were commissioned for already successful books. These illustrated versions were usually published as limited editions and sold through prior subscription. [[Henry Fuseli]] created a single frontispiece for the fourth edition of [[Tobias Smollett]]'s ''[[The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle]]''. [[Thomas Stothard]] provided several illustrations for an edition of ''[[The Vicar of Wakefield]]'' published 30 years after its first publication in 1766.<ref name=Charlespg4/>
Near the end of the 18th century, new mechanical techniques allowed pictures to be printed cheaply. Illustrated classics became cheaply available, and were strongly remembered by their readers. [[John Ruskin]] was moved by illustrations of [[Robinson Crusoe]] crashing into rocks and escaping his wreck. [[Charles Dickens]] remembered the illustrations in many books more than the prose itself.<ref name=Charlespg4/>
== Illustrated fiction in the 19th century == [[File:George Cruikshank Oliver Twist.gif|thumb|250px|right|"Please, sir, I want some more." From ''[[Oliver Twist]]'', illustration by [[George Cruikshank]].]] At the beginning of the 19th century, illustration increased the sales of previously published fiction. In 1836, the publication of Charles Dickens's ''[[The Pickwick Papers]]'' in an illustrated serialized format revolutionised the publication of new fiction.<ref name=Charlespg4/> The popularity of the original illustrations in Dickens's novels was unprecedented, and helped to popularize the use of illustrations in serious fiction.<ref name=Charlespg229-233>Cohen 1980, page 229-233.</ref> This revolution lasted until 1870, as other authors and published attempted to emulate Dickens's success. Illustrations became common in the period. For publishers, new fiction with illustrations published serially was less of a commercial risk than the traditional unillustrated three-volume sets. Illustrations attracted readers and increased advertising revenue. Illustrations were used as advertisement's in booksellers windows.<ref name=Charlespg4/>
During the 19th century, the use of photomechanical techniques decreased the cost of reproducing illustrations. Both colour and black and white illustrations were increasingly used in daily, weekly, and monthly publications. Publishers sold a great deal of one-volume hardcovers and periodical serials.<ref name=Charlespg229-233/>
Dickens's novels were well-suited to graphic representation. Dickens believed that the drawings that illustrated his fiction were valuable,<ref name=Charlespg229-233/> despite some critics urging him not to use them. Most of his major works were originally published with illustrations. He was intensely involved in the creation of most of the 900 original illustrations of his writing. These illustrations were produced by 18 artists,<ref name=Charlespg3>Cohen 1980, page 3.</ref> including [[George Cruikshank]] and [[Robert Seymour (illustrator)|Robert Seymour]].<ref name=Charlespg6>Cohen 1980, page 6.</ref>
Most of [[William Harrison Ainsworth|William Ainsworth]]'s, [[Charles Lever]]'s, [[William Thackeray]]'s, and [[Anthony Trollope]]'s major works were initially published in illustrated monthly parts. Later, novelists preferred to publish their writing in illustrated magazines. [[Thomas Hardy]] often did this. [[George Meredith]] did this twice, and [[George Eliot]] once.<ref name=Charlespg5>Cohen 1980, page 5.</ref> 19th century author artists included [[William Makepeace Thackeray]] and [[George du Maurier]].<ref name=Charlespg229-233/>
Many artists began their careers illustrating fiction. Illustrating was a difficult and badly paid job. [[Hablot Knight Browne]] was one of the few very talented artists to pursue illustrating full-time. Most artists, such as [[Marcus Stone]] and [[Luke Fildes]], used illustrating as a stepping-stone to a career in painting. Other artists like [[George Cattermole]] and [[Daniel Maclise]] supplemented their income by providing illustrations.<ref name=Charlespg6/>
The popularity of illustrated fiction began to decline in the late 19th century, as illustrations lost their novelty and no longer guaranteed that a novel would sell well.<ref name=Charlespg229-233/> Technological improvements in printing flooded the market with affordable novels with illustrations of high quality. Prestigious artists including [[John Everett Millais]], [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]], [[Edward Burne-Jones]], and [[Frederick Leighton]] started to illustrate books. Illustrations challenged the novel's prose, implying a failure in prose's self-sufficiency.<ref name=Elliottpg47>Elliott, Kamilla, 2003, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GM7TqTLYKogC ''Rethinking the Novel/Film Debate''], Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-81844-3}}, page 47.</ref> Prose frequently took second place to illustration.<ref name=Elliottpg48>Elliott 2003, page 48.</ref>
== Illustrated fiction in the 20th century == The amount of illustrated fiction that was published declined from the beginning of the 20th century to the 1930s. By the 1930s, illustrations were rarely used in adult's novels.<ref name=Elliottpg49>Elliott 2003, page 49.</ref> Illustrated serious fiction was not popular over the rest of the century. The decline in the publication of serials, rise in labour costs, and competition from film, television, and photojournalism contributed to its decline. There was also less demand from readers.<ref name=Charlespg229-233/> Historians of Western illustrated fiction mostly agree that film replaced the illustrated book.<ref name=Stampg10>Stam, Robert, and Raengo, Alessandra, 2004, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aA6VaCzSyCYC ''A Companion to Literature and Film''], Blackwell Publishing, {{ISBN|0-631-23053-X}}, page 10.</ref> A review of the 1915 film adaptation of ''Vanity Fair'' said that "the reels make a set of illustrations superior to the conventional pen-pictures of a deluxe edition."<ref name=Elliottpg51>Elliott 2003, page 51.</ref>
Modern literary fiction was often not well-suited to illustration, for example the introspective novels of [[E. M. Forster]] and [[Virginia Woolf]]. Illustrations were used on book covers to attract buyers, but not used within the novel. Similar to the period before 1836, illustrations were not commissioned for new books, but were commissioned for established classics, usually for a limited luxury edition. Serious novels are not illustrated, and illustrated fiction is generally associated with serialized or short fiction that is published in popular but not intellectually prestigious magazines. Children and comics readers became the only fiction readers whose fiction was generally illustrated.<ref name=Charlespg229-233/>
Some authors were concerned that illustrations would date or misinterpret their prose.<ref name=Charlespg229-233/> [[Henry James]] disliked illustrations, claiming that illustrations were not needed because prose was sufficiently pictorial. He thought that illustrations and prose were in competition with one another.<ref name=Elliottpg48/> He permitted his travel books, but not his mature fiction, to be illustrated. [[Alvin Langdon Coburn]]'s photographs were used in the New York edition of his works only as [[Book frontispiece|frontispiece]]s, and only after James reassured himself that they did not compete or make a reference to his prose. Similar to James, Thomas Hardy increasingly excluded illustrations from the collected editions of his novels, with the exception of maps that he had drawn and photographic frontispieces.<ref name=Charlespg229-233/>
None of the first or standard editions of [[James Joyce]]'s novels were illustrated during his lifetime, except for an edition of ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'' published by the Limited Editions Club in 1935, which included drawings and etchings by [[Henri Matisse]]. [[Pearl Buck]]'s husband [[Richard J. Walsh]], as editor of [[Asia (magazine)|Asia]], included illustrations with Buck's work that was published there in serial or complete form. However, as editor and later president of the [[John Day Company]], he did not include illustrations in the subsequent hardcover editions of these novels. When [[Ernest Hemingway]]'s novella ''[[The Old Man and the Sea]]'' was first published in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine in 1952, it was illustrated with blue-tinted drawings by [[Noel Sickles]]. These illustrations were not included in its first publication in volume form, published by [[Charles Scribner's Sons]].<ref name=Charlespg229-233/>
In the middle of the 20th century, the comic strip using visual images to convey action were a great influence on children and young people.<ref name=Sillars/> Comic books had a unique storytelling potential.<ref name=Harvey>Harvey, Robert C., 1996, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vAH24kOdCq8C ''The Art of the Comic Book: An Aesthetic History''] University Press of Mississippi, {{ISBN|0-87805-758-7}}.</ref>
== See also == *[[Comic book]] *[[Manga]] *[[Victorian literature]]

{{DEFAULTSORT:Illustrated Fiction}} [[Category:Comics terminology]] [[Category:Illustration]]

{{Infobox person | name = John Mulholland | image = John Mulholland magician.png | occupation = [[Magic (illusion)|Magician]] | birth_date = 9 June 1898 | death_date = {{d-da|25 February 1970|9 June 1898}} }}
'''John Mulholland''' (9 June 1898 in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]] – 25 February 1970 in [[New York City]]) was an American [[Magic (illusion)|magician]], author, publisher and [[Espionage|intelligence agent]].
==Life and work==
Mulholland learned the art of magic as a teenager with John William Sargent, President of the [[Society of American Magicians]]. Mulholland was a professional magician for two decades, working in small companies and large stage shows. He ran one of the first magic workshops and was from 1930 the editor of the magical trade magazine ''[[The Sphinx: An Independent Magazine for Magicians|The Sphinx]]''. He published many books on magic and its history.
Mulholland was a close friend of [[Harry Houdini]].<ref>Basbanes, Nicholas A. (1995). ''A Gentle Madness: Bibliophiles, Bibliomanes, and the Eternal Passion for Books''. Henry Holt and Company. p. 419</ref> Mulholland asserted that "Houdini once told me that he considered no man to be a magician until he was able skillfully to perform the [[cups and balls]]."<ref>Osborne, Thomas James. (1937). ''Cups and Balls Magic''. Kanter's Magic Shop. p. 8</ref>
His other friends included [[Gene Tunney]], [[Harold Ross]] and Bert Terhune.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15276667/new_york_day_by_day_by_o_o_mcintyre/|title=New York Day by Day by O. O. McIntyre, John Mullholland (1936)|date=1936-09-09|work=Valley Morning Star|access-date=2017-11-21|pages=8}}</ref>
In 1939, he was the only foreign officer in the British Magical Society, and by that time had studied his craft in 42 countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15276716/flowers_will_grow_before_your_eyes_in/|title=Flowers will grow before your eyes in Rainbow show, John Mullholland (1939)|date=1939|work=El Paso Herald-Post|access-date=2017-11-21|pages=2}}</ref>
During [[World War II]], he wrote a spellbook for soldiers. His impressive collection is now owned by [[David Copperfield (illusionist)|David Copperfield]].
He was the editor of the Conjurer's Journal and was the only living magician listed in the book [[Who’s Who in America|''Who's who in America'']] immediately after the death of [[Howard Thurston]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15276565/magicians_to_entertain_by_clever/|title=Magicians to entertain by clever tricks, John Mullholland (1936)|date=1936-05-07|work=Enterprise-Journal|access-date=2017-11-21|pages=6}}</ref>
He left his editorial position at ''The Sphinx'' in 1953, officially due to health problems but actually to work for the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]].
During the [[Cold War]], Mulholland was paid by the CIA to write a manual on [[deception]] and [[Misdirection (magic)|misdirection]]. Copies of the document were believed to have been destroyed in 1973, however, copies later resurfaced and were published as "The Official CIA Manual of Trickery and Deception".<ref>[https://www.wired.com/2009/11/cias-lost-magic-manual-resurfaces/ "CIA's Lost Magic Manual Resurfaces"]. Retrieved 24 May 2016.</ref>
In 2008, magician Ben Robinson authored ''The Magician: John Mulholland's Secret Life'' which documented his work with the CIA.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/secret-cia-magic-manual-reveals-cold-war-spy/story?id=9229248 "Secret CIA 'Magic' Manual Reveals Cold War Spy Tricks"]. Retrieved 24 May 2016.</ref>
==Skepticism==
Mulholland had criticized the claims of [[parapsychology]] and exposed the tricks of fraudulent spiritualist [[Mediumship|mediums]]. His book ''Beware Familiar Spirits'' (1938) revealed many of these tricks.<ref name="Review 1938">The New Books. [http://www.unz.org/Pub/SaturdayRev-1938nov26-00022 ''Review of Beware Familiar Spirits'']. The Saturday Review. November 26, 1938. p. 24</ref><ref>Coleman, Earle Jerome. (1987). ''Magic: A Reference Guide''. Greenwood Press. p. 120</ref>
A review which highly praised the book, stated that Mulholland had "been sworn at, threatened, and even shot at while acquiring the information".<ref name="Review 1938"/>
In 1952 for ''[[Popular Science]]'', he published a skeptical article on [[flying saucer]]s and [[Unidentified flying object|UFOs]].
==Books== [[File:John Mulholland magician 2.png|thumb|350px|Advert for Mulholland]]
'''Articles'''
*[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YCgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA17&dq=fortune-telling&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiEpPD86ZrTAhVkLcAKHZwRCIkQuwUIHDAA#v=onepage&q=fortune-telling&f=false ''Secrets of the Fortune-Telling Racket'']. ''[[Popular Science]]''. January, 1931. [with Michel Mok] *[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=SiEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA98&dq=John+Mulholland&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwib6oP1tJzTAhXkDMAKHX2ODH0QuwUIHjAA#v=onepage&q=John%20Mulholland&f=false ''Magicians Scoff'']. ''[[Popular Science]]''. September, 1952.
'''Books'''
* ''Magic in the Making'' (1925) * ''Quicker than the Eye'' (1932) * ''The Magic and Magicians of the World'' (1932) * ''The Story of Magic'' (1935) * ''Beware Familiar Spirits'' (1938) * ''The Girl in the Cage'' (1939) * ''The Art of Illusion'' (1944) * ''The Early Magic Shows'' (1945) * ''The Official CIA Manual of Trickery and Deception'' (1953) * ''Practical Puppetry'' (1961) * ''John Mulholland’s Book of Magic'' (1963) * ''Magic of the World'' (1965) * ''The Magical Mind -- Key to Successful Communication'' (1967)

{{Authority control}}

{{See also|List of world's fairs}} '''List of world expositions''' is an annotated list of every [[World's fair|world exposition]] sanctioned by the [[Bureau International des Expositions]] (BIE), including those recognised retrospectively as they took place (long) before BIE came into existence. The designation "World Exposition" or "Expo" refers to a class of the largest, general scope exhibitions of 3 to 6 months' duration. This list does not include BIE recognized International Horticultural Exhibitions. For other major international exhibitions, in addition to those endorsed by the BIE, see the comprehensive [[list of world's fairs]]. == Category == {| cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" |- |''World Expo'' |BIE-International Registered exhibitions that take place every 5 years and last up to 6 months. revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2009}} '''Music Allies''' is a marketing company that promotes 20+ [[independent record labels]] and major [[music festivals]]. It was started in January 2003 by Sean O'Connell. Successful artists include [[Ani DiFranco]], [[Aimee Mann]], [[G. Love]], [[Animal Liberation Orchestra|ALO]], [[Joan Osborne]], [[Sia Furler|Sia]], the [[Bacon Brothers]], [[Sonya Kitchell]], [[Zee Avi]], [[Joshua James (folk singer)|Joshua James]], [[Martin Sexton]] and the [[Blind Boys of Alabama]].<ref>Radio and Records Nov 25 2005</ref>
Labels that utilize Music Allies include [[Righteous Babe Records]], [[Tennman Records]], [[Brushfire Records]] and [[Time Life]].
Major festivals represented by Music Allies include [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]],<ref>Nashville Scene June 14, 2007</ref><ref>Mix Magazine September 2009</ref> the [[Outside Lands Festival]], [[Camp Bisco]], the 10k Lakes Festival and the now defunct [[Vegoose]], Echo Project and [[Langerado]] Music Festivals.
Music Allies produces and syndicates the [[Warren Haynes]] Christmas Jam radio special.
The company is located in [[Asheville, North Carolina]].
According to their Linked In company profile, Music Allies is a privately held company with 12 employees based in Asheville, NC, Virginia, and Atlanta, GA.<ref>Linked In Sep 2009</ref>
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.musicallies.com] Official Music Allies website * [http://www.linkedin.com/companies/music-allies] Music Allies Linked In Company Profile <!--- see [[Help:Interlanguage links]] -->
[[Category:Companies based in Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:Companies established in 2003]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]]

{{redirect|Fictional film|films that only exist in fiction|Story within a story}} '''Narrative film''', '''fictional film''' or '''fiction film''' is a [[film]] that tells a [[fictional]] or fictionalized story, event or [[narrative]]. In this style of film, believable narratives and characters help convince the audience that the unfolding fiction is real. Lighting and camera movement, among other cinematic elements, have become increasingly important in these films. Great detail goes into the [[screenplay]]s of narratives, as these films rarely deviate from the predetermined behaviours and lines of the classical style of [[screenplay]] writing to maintain a sense of realism. Actors must deliver dialogue and action in a believable way, so as to persuade the audience that the film is real life.
==General== Probably the first fictional film ever made was the [[Auguste and Louis Lumière|Lumière's]] ''L'Arroseur arrosé'', which was first screened at the Grand Café Capucines on December 28, 1895.<ref>Alison McMahan, ''Alice Guy Blaché, Lost Visionary of the Cinema'' (New York: Continuum, 2002) p. 13.</ref> A year later in 1896, [[Alice Guy-Blaché]] directed the fictional film ''La fee aux choux''. Yet perhaps the best known of early fictional films is [[Georges Méliès]]’s ''[[A Trip to the Moon]]'' from 1902.<ref>Rosalind Leveridge, “Fantastic voyages of the cinematic imagination: George Méliès’s Trip to the Moon” ''Early Popular Visual Culture'' (May 2012), 10 (2), pg. 197-199</ref> Most films previous to this had been merely moving images of everyday occurrences, such as ''[[L'Arrivée d'un train en gare de La Ciotat]]'' by [[Auguste and Louis Lumière]]. Méliès was one of the first directors to progress cinematic technology, which paved the way for narratives as style of film.<ref>Rosalind Leveridge, “Fantastic voyages of the cinematic imagination: George Méliès’s Trip to the Moon” ''Early Popular Visual Culture'' (May 2012), 10 (2), pg. 197-199</ref> Narrative films have come so far since their introduction that [[film genres]] such as [[comedy]] or [[Western (genre)|Western]] films, were, and continue to be introduced as a way to further categorize these films.<ref>Barsam, Richard Meran and Dave Monahan. ''Looking at Movies: An Introduction to Film''. New York: W.W. Norton &, 2010</ref>
Narrative cinema is usually contrasted to films that present information, such as a nature [[Documentary film|documentary]], as well as to some [[experimental film]]s (works such as [[Wavelength (1966 film)|''Wavelength'']] by [[Michael Snow]], ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' by [[Dziga Vertov]], or films by [[Chantal Akerman]]). In some instances pure documentary films, while [[nonfiction]], may nonetheless recount a story. As genres evolve, from fiction film and [[documentary]] a [[Wiktionary:hybrid|hybrid]] one emerged, [[docufiction]].
Many films are based on real occurrences, however these too fall under the category of a “narrative film” rather than a [[Documentary film|documentary]]. This is because films based on real occurrences are not simply footage of the occurrence, but rather hired actors portraying an adjusted, often more dramatic, retelling of the occurrence (such as ''[[21 (2008 film)|21]]'' by [[Robert Luketic]]).<ref>Barsam, Richard Meran and Dave Monahan. ''Looking at Movies: An Introduction to Film''. New York: W.W. Norton &, 2010</ref>
Unlike literary fiction, which is typically based on characters, situations and events that are entirely imaginary/fictional/hypothetical, cinema always has a real referent, called the "pro-filmic", which encompasses everything existing and done in front of the camera.
Since the emergence of [[Classical Hollywood cinema|classical Hollywood]] style in the early 20th century, during which films were selected to be made based on the popularity of the genre, stars, producers, and directors involved, narrative, usually in the form of the [[feature film]], has held dominance in commercial cinema and has become popularly synonymous with "the movies."<ref>Kaplan, E. Ann. ''Women and Film: Both Sides of the Camera''. New York: Methuen, 1988</ref> Classical, invisible filmmaking (what is often called [[realism (arts)|realist]] fiction) is central to this popular definition. This key element of this invisible filmmaking lies in [[continuity editing]].
== See also == {{commons category|Cinema}}
*[[Film genre]] *[[Non-narrative film]] *[[Drama (genre)]], which deals mainly with film.
==References== {{Reflist}} * [[David Bordwell]], Mark Dherrick Cuevas, and [[Kristin Thompson]]. 1997. ''Film Art: An Introduction''. Fifth ed. New York: The McGraw-Hill Companies. {{ISBN|0-07-114073-5}}.
