[[af:Rolprent Genres]] [[et:Mängufilm]] [[it:Generi cinematografici]] [[ka:მხატვრული ფილმი]] [[mk:Листа на филмски жанрови]] [[nl:Filmgenre]] [[ja:映画のジャンル]] [[pt:Lista de gêneros cinematográficos]] [[ru:Игровое кино]] [[sv:Filmgenre]]

{{multiple issues| {{original research|date=September 2016}} {{refimprove|date=September 2016}} }} A '''one-liner''' is a [[joke]] that is delivered in a single line. A good one-liner is said to be [[wikt:pithy|pithy]] - concise and meaningful.<ref>The Unuttered Punch Line:Pragmatic Incongruity and the Parsing of “What’s the Difference” Jokes, K.E.L. Miller, [http://engling.truman.edu/SeniorSem/PDFpapers/Miller%20paper%20PDF.pdf]</ref> Comedians and actors use this comedic method as part of their act, e.g. [[Jimmy Carr]], [[Tommy Cooper]], [[Rodney Dangerfield]], [[Norm Macdonald]], [[Ken Dodd]], [[Stewart Francis]], [[Zach Galifianakis]], [[Mitch Hedberg]], [[Anthony Jeselnik]], [[Milton Jones]], [[Shappi Khorsandi]], [[Jay London]], [[Mark Linn-Baker]], [[Demetri Martin]], [[Groucho Marx]], [[Dan Mintz]], [[Emo Philips]], [[Tim Vine]], [[Steven Wright]] and [[Henny Youngman]] and [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]].{{cn|date=September 2016}} Many fictional characters are also known to deliver one-liners, including [[James Bond]], who usually includes pithy and laconic quips after disposing of a villain.{{cn|date=September 2016}}
==Examples== * "A baby seal walks into a club." * "A dyslexic man walks into a bra." (Anonymous) * "There are three types of people, those who can count and those who can't." * "Venison's dear, isn't it?" ([[Jimmy Carr]]) * "An escalator cannot break, it can only become stairs." ([[Mitch Hedberg]]) * "Race is just a pigment of the imagination." (Glen Highland) * "What Iran needs now is a more modern leader—a mullah lite." ([[Shappi Khorsandi]]) * "I have nothing to declare except my genius." ([[Oscar Wilde]], upon arriving at US customs, 1882)<ref name="cwq-64300">{{cite web | year = 1996 | url = http://www.bartleby.com/66/0/64300.html | title = Number 64300 | work = The Columbia World of Quotations | accessdate = 2007-06-20 }}</ref> * "Take my wife ... please." ([[Henny Youngman]]) * "They hired a 3-piece band that was so lousy, every time the waiter dropped a tray, we all got up and danced!" ([[Les Dawson]]) * "What a magnificent show this is going to be when it starts!" ([[Ken Dodd]]) * "Infamy, infamy, they've all got it in for me" ([[Kenneth Williams]] playing [[Julius Caesar]] in ''[[Carry On Cleo]]'') * "I have an L-shaped sofa... Lowercase." ([[Demetri Martin]]) * “Crime in multi-story car parks is wrong on so many different levels.” ([[Tim Vine]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://inews.co.uk/culture/100-best-jokes-one-liners-edinburgh-fringe/|title=100 of the best ever jokes and one-liners from the Edinburgh Fringe|date=2017-08-04|work=iNews|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>)
== See also ==
*[[Greguería]] *[[Paraprosdokian]] *[[Throwaway line]]
== References ==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Jokes]]

{{Forensic science|articles|image=Raymond Burr Barbara Hale Perry Mason 1958.jpg}} The '''Perry Mason syndrome''' is the manner in which the television crime drama ''[[Perry Mason (TV series)|Perry Mason]]'' (1957–1966) may have affected perceptions of the [[United States legal system]] among [[defendant]]s and [[juror]]s.
==Typical ''Perry Mason'' episode== In a typical episode of ''Perry Mason'', a series involving a fictional Los Angeles defense attorney which initially ran from September 1957 to May 1966, the first half of the show usually depicted the prospective murder victim as being deserving of homicide, often with Mason's client publicly threatening to kill the victim. After Mason's client is charged with murder, during the [[preliminary hearing]] for the trial Mason would establish his client's innocence by dramatically demonstrating the guilt of another character.<ref name="Leitch">{{Cite book |last=Leitch |first=Thomas |authorlink= |title=Perry Mason |publisher=Wayne State University Press |year=2005 |location=Detroit |pages=28–29 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zLi1H936-1kC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=0-8143-3121-1}}</ref> The real murderer would nearly always break down and confess to the crime in the courtroom, often while on the witness stand.<ref name="Leitch"/>
== Jurors == The Perry Mason syndrome purports that, due to the oversimplified manner in which trial proceedings were presented on the popular crime drama ''[[Perry Mason (TV series)|Perry Mason]]'', jurors who watched the program would enter trials with misconceptions about how the legal process works.<ref name="Dictator">{{cite journal | title = The Great Electronic Dictator | url = http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/content/abstract/61/5/684 | author = Boorstin, Daniel J. | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 61 | issue = 5 | date = May 1978 | page = 684 }}</ref> Some argue that the Perry Mason syndrome greatly reinforced the [[presumption of innocence]] of the defendant, which may have been problematic when the defendant was [[Guilt (law)|guilty]].<ref name="Lippman">{{cite news | title = The actor who has played Perry Mason on... | url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1993-09-16/news/1993259073_1_perry-mason-mason-syndrome-played-perry | author = Lippman Jr., Theo | date = 16 September 1993 | publisher = Baltimore Sun | accessdate = 25 December 2010 }}</ref> Others argue that, because Perry Mason was often able to cause [[witness]]es to [[Confession (law)|confess]], jurors would expect similar "[[Perry Mason moment]]s" to occur in real trials as well.<ref name="Symposium">{{cite conference | page = 11 | title = The Potential Impact of Television on Jurors | author = Podlas, Kimberlianne | url = http://projects.nfstc.org/ipes/presentations/Podlas_tv-jurors.pdf | conference = August 2010 Impression and Pattern Evidence Symposium | publisher = [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]] }}</ref> This shifted the [[Legal burden of proof|burden of proof]] from the [[prosecution]] to the defense.<ref name="Symposium"/> In one case, a juror told the defense attorney that the jury had voted to convict the defendant because the prosecution's key witness did not confess during [[cross-examination]].<ref name="Graham">{{cite journal | title = The Impact of Television on the Jury System: Ancient Myths and Modern Realism | url = http://www.wcl.american.edu/journal/lawrev/40/graham.pdf?rd=1 | last =Graham |first=Fred | author-link = | journal = American University Law Review | year =1991 | volume = 40| issue =2 | page = 628 |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20120304114716/http://www.wcl.american.edu/journal/lawrev/40/graham.pdf?rd=1|archive-date=March 4, 2012}}</ref>
== Defendants == The Perry Mason syndrome has been cited as a reason some defendants would choose to appear ''[[pro se]]''—representing oneself in court rather than being represented by a [[lawyer]]. The simplified portrayals of trials on the television series led some defendants to underestimate the seriousness of their predicaments.<ref name="Scott">{{cite journal | title = The Role of Standby Counsel: The Road From Faretta To Wiggins | last = Scott |first=Teresa A. | journal = Howard Law Journal | url = https://litigation-essentials.lexisnexis.com/webcd/app?action=DocumentDisplay&crawlid=1&doctype=cite&docid=27+How.+L.J.+1799&srctype=smi&srcid=3B15&key=04c43a32488869fdf427836808d2c332 | year = 1984 |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20160304040232/https://litigation-essentials.lexisnexis.com/webcd/app?action=DocumentDisplay&crawlid=1&doctype=cite&docid=27+How.+L.J.+1799&srctype=smi&srcid=3B15&key=04c43a32488869fdf427836808d2c332|archive-date=March 4, 2016|subscription=true|publisher=[[LexisNexis]]}}</ref> Consistent viewers of the show may have also believed that they had gained an intimate understanding of the [[United States legal system]] and would be able to represent themselves better than an attorney could.<ref name="Library">{{cite journal | title = Reference Librarian and the Pro Se Patron | author = Begg, Robert T. | journal = Law Library Journal | volume = 69 | page = 29 | ssrn = 1616815 | year = 1976}}</ref> This effect may have been exacerbated by the tendency for [[news media]] to oversimplify their coverage of trial proceedings.<ref name="Library"/>
==See also== *[[Criminal procedure in the United States]] *[[CSI effect]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Perry Mason}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Perry Mason Syndrome}} [[Category:United States law]] [[Category:Crime drama]] [[Category:Perry Mason]]

revision.comment: formatted 1 ref/* Pin-up in the contemporary age */
revision.text:
{{redirect|Pinup|other uses|Pin-up (disambiguation)}} {{cleanup|reason=flow, style - some portions are a bit essay-like|date=June 2018}} [[File:Betty Grable 20th Century Fox.jpg|thumb|[[Betty Grable]]'s famous pin-up photo from 1943]] A '''pin-up model''' (known as a '''pin-up girl''' for a female and less commonly '''male pin-up''' for a male) is a [[model (person)|model]] whose mass-produced pictures see wide appeal as popular culture. Pin-ups are intended for informal display, i.e. meant to be "''pinned-up''" on a wall. Pin-up models may be [[glamour photography|glamour models]], fashion models, or actors. These pictures are also sometimes known as '''cheesecake''' photos.{{efn|''[[Merriam-Webster]] Online'' defines a "cheesecake" as "a photographic display of shapely and scantily clothed female figure".}} Cheesecake was an American slang word, that was considered a publicly acceptable term for seminude women because pin-up was considered taboo in the early twentieth century.{{Cite journal|last=Meyerowitz|first=Joanne|date=1996|title=Women, Cheesecake, and Borderline Material: Responses to Girlie Pictures in the Mid-Twentieth-Century U.S.|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/363799/summary|journal=Journal of Women's History|language=en|volume=8|issue=3|pages=9–35|doi=10.1353/jowh.2010.0424|issn=1527-2036}} The term ''pin-up'' may refer to drawings, paintings, and other illustrations as well as photographs (see the [[list of pin-up artists]]). The term was first attested to in English in 1941;{{sfnp|Ayto|2006|p=126}} however, the practice is documented back at least to the 1890s. Pin-up images could be cut out of magazines or newspapers, or on a postcard or [[lithography|lithograph]]. Such pictures often appear on walls, desks, or calendars. [[Poster]]s of pin-ups were mass-produced, and became popular from the mid 20th century. Male pin-ups were less common than their female counterparts throughout the 20th century, although a market for [[homoerotica]] has always existed as well as pictures of popular male celebrities targeted at women or girls. Examples include [[James Dean]] and [[Jim Morrison]]. ==History== Beginning in the early nineteenth century, pin-up modeling had "theatrical origins",{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/62281839|title=Pin-up grrrls : feminism, sexuality, popular culture|last=1971-|first=Buszek, Maria Elena,|date=2006|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=0822337347|location=Durham|oclc=62281839}} [[American burlesque|burlesque]] performers and actresses sometimes used photographic advertisement as business cards to advertise shows.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/62281839|title=Pin-up grrrls : feminism, sexuality, popular culture|last=1971-|first=Buszek, Maria Elena,|date=2006|publisher=Duke University Press|year=|isbn=0822337347|location=Durham|pages=43|oclc=62281839}} These adverts and business cards could often be found backstage in almost every theater's [[green room]], pinned-up or stuck into "frames of the looking-glasses, in the joints of the gas-burners, and sometimes lying on-top of the sacred cast-case itself." Understanding the power of photographic advertisements to promote their shows, burlesque women self-constructed their identity to make themselves visible. Being recognized not only within the theater itself but also outside challenged the conventions of women's place and women's potential in the public sphere.{{Cite book|title=Pin-up grrrls: feminism, sexuality, popular culture|last=Buszek|first=Maria Elena|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2006|isbn=0-8223-3746-0|location=Duke University Press.|pages=45}} "To understand both the complicated identity and the subversive nature of the 19th-century actress, one must also understand that the era's views on women's potential were inextricably tied to their sexuality, which in turn was tied to their level of visibility in the public sphere: regardless of race, class or background, it was generally assumed that the more public the woman, the more 'public,' or available, her sexuality, according to historian Maria Elena Buszek. Being sexually fantasized, famous actresses in early 20th-century film were both drawn and photographed and put on posters to be sold for personal entertainment.Carole S. Vance, ed. "Seeking Ectasy on the Battlefield: Danger and Pleasure in Nineteenth-Century Feminist Sexual Thought," in Pleasure and Danger: Exploring Female Sexuality (Boston: Routledge and K. Paul, 1984) Among the [[celebrity|celebrities]] who were considered [[sex symbol]]s, one of the most popular early pin-up girls was [[Betty Grable]], whose poster was ubiquitous in the lockers of [[GI (term)|G.I.]]s during [[World War II]]. [[File:Bernie Dexter.jpg|thumb|left|upright|American pin-up model [[Bernie Dexter]]]] In Europe, prior to the First World War, the likes of [[Fernande Barrey]] (aka "Miss Fernande"), were arguably the world's first pin-ups as is known in the modern sense. Miss Barrey displayed ample cleavage and full frontal nudity. Her pictures were cherished by soldiers on both sides of the First World War conflict.[http://dazzledent.tumblr.com/post/9537692783/her-name-was-fernande-barrey-but-she-was-known Dazzledent: Fernande Barrey; tumblr] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005000322/http://dazzledent.tumblr.com/post/9537692783/her-name-was-fernande-barrey-but-she-was-known |date=2013-10-05 }}[http://home.comcast.net/~kb8gpo/fernande/ Miss Fernande; Comcast.net] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004213236/http://home.comcast.net/~kb8gpo/fernande/ |date=2013-10-04 }} [[File:Nose art on the B-25J Take-off Time.JPG|thumb|Pin-up girl nose art on the restored World War II [[North American B-25 Mitchell|B-25J]] aircraft ''Take-off Time'']] Other pin-ups were artwork depicting idealized versions of what some thought a particularly beautiful or attractive woman should look like. An early example of the latter type was the [[Gibson girl]], a representation of the [[New Woman]] drawn by [[Charles Dana Gibson]]. "Because the New Woman was symbolic of her new ideas about her sex, it was inevitable that she would also come to symbolize new ideas about sexuality."{{sfnp|Buszek|2006|p=82}} Unlike the photographed actresses and dancers generations earlier, fantasy gave artists the freedom to draw women in many different ways.{{sfnp|Buszek|2006|p=43}} The 1932 Esquire "men's" magazine featured many drawings and "girlie" cartoons but was most famous for its [[Alberto Vargas|''Vargas girls'']]. Prior to World War II they were praised for their beauty and less focus was on their sexuality. However, during the war, the drawings transformed into women playing dress-up in military drag and drawn in seductive manners, like that of a child playing with a doll.{{sfnp|Buszek|2006|p=209}} The Vargas girls became so popular that from 1942–46, owing to a high volume of military demand, "9 million copies of the magazine-without adverts and free of charge was sent to American troops stationed overseas and in domestic bases."{{sfnp|Buszek|2006|p=210}} The Vargas Girls were adapted as [[nose art]] on many [[World War II]] bomber and fighter aircraft; Generally, they were considered inspiring, and not seen negatively, or as prostitutes, but mostly as inspiring female patriots that were helpful for good luck.{{cite book|last=Costello|first=John|title=Virtue Under Fire: How World War II Changed Our social and Sexual Attitudes|year=1985|publisher=Little Brown|location=Boston|isbn=0-316-73968-5|pages=144–155}} Among the other well-known artists specializing in the field were [[Earle K. Bergey]], [[Enoch Bolles]], [[Gil Elvgren]], [[George Petty]], [[Rolf Armstrong]], [[Zoë Mozert]], [[Duane Bryers]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2385046/Hilda-Fifties-plus-size-pin-rediscovered-year-creator-Duane-Bryers-dies.html|title=How Hilda the forgotten Fifties plus-size pin-up was rediscovered one year after the man who created her died|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nogalesinternational.com/the_bulletin/news/noted-artist-duane-bryers-dies-at/article_971c16f8-aff0-11e1-a9c2-001a4bcf887a.html|title=Noted artist Duane Bryers dies at 100|first=JB Miller The|last=Bulletin|publisher=}} and [[Art Frahm]]. Notable contemporary pin-up artists include [[Olivia De Berardinis]], known for her pin-up art of [[Bettie Page]] and her pieces in ''[[Playboy]]''. ==Feminism and the pin-up== Many people believe that since its beginnings the pin-up “...has presented women with models for expressing and finding pleasure in their sexual subjectivity”. According to [[Joanne Meyerowitz]] in "Women, Cheesecake, and Borderline Material" an article in ''Journal of Women's History'', "As sexual images of women multiplied in the popular culture, women participated actively in constructing arguments to endorse as well as protest them."{{sfnp|Meyerowitz|1996|p=9}} As early as 1869, women have been supporters and protesters of the pin-up. Female supporters of early pin-up content considered these to be a "positive post-Victorian rejection of bodily shame and a healthy respect for female beauty."{{sfnp|Meyerowitz|1996|p=10}} Additionally, pin-up allows for women to change the everyday culture. The models “...succeed in the feminist aim of changing the rigid, patriarchal terms”.{{Cite book|title=Pin-Up Grrrls: Feminism, Sexuality, Popular Culture|last=Buszek|first=Maria Elena|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2007|isbn=|location=|pages=}} It has further been argued by some critics that in the early 20th century, these drawings of women helped define certain body images—such as being clean, being healthy, and being wholesome—and were enjoyed by both men and women; as time progressed these images changed from respectable to illicit.{{sfnp|Ross|1989|p=61}} Conversely, female protesters argued that these images were corrupting societal morality and saw these public sexual displays of women as lowering the standards of [[womanhood]], destroying their dignity, reducing them to mere objects to pleasure men and therefore harmful to both women and young adolescents.{{sfnp|Meyerowitz|1996|p=10}} Pin-up modeling is a subculture that is invested in promoting positive body images and a love for one's sexuality, “...pin-up would also find ways to… encourage the erotic self-awareness and self expression of real women". == Hair and makeup style == [[File:Joan Crawford 1946 by Paul Hesse.jpg|thumb|upright|1946 photo by Paul Hesse of [[Joan Crawford]] Adorning the iconic "Hunter's Bow", or over-drawn, lip, and her hair pinned up in Victorian rolls]] The classic style of the pin-up originates back from the 1940s. Due to the shortages of materials during WWII, this period of makeup is considered the "natural beauty" look.{{Cite book|title=Classic Beauty: The History of Makeup|last=Hernandez|first=Gabriela|publisher=Schiffer Publishing LTD|year=2017|isbn=0764353004|location=United States|pages=}} The US was immersed in [[war-time economy]], which put distribution restrictions on consumer goods.Tassava, Christopher. “The American Economy during World War II”. EH.Net Encyclopedia, edited by Robert Whaples. February 10, 2008. URL http://eh.net/encyclopedia/the-american-economy-during-world-war-ii/ General rationing was supported; women applied mild amounts of products. Despite the rations, "Women were encouraged to keep buying lipstick and to send letters to the front covered in 'lipstick kisses' to boost the morale of the soldiers." The products consisted of: *''"Foundation – A cream base, liquid foundation that matched their natural skin tone,'' "having a sun-kissed glow was popular among white women.{{Cite news|url=http://hair-and-makeup-artist.com/womens-1940s-makeup/|title=Women's 1940s Makeup: An Overview - Hair and Makeup Artist Handbook|date=2013-01-30|work=Hair and Makeup Artist Handbook|access-date=2018-05-05|language=en-US}} *''Compact Powders – used to set the foundation and even the overall complexion.'' *''Eyes and brows – neutral contour on brow bone and lid. Eyebrows were shaped but kept full.'' *''Eyeliner – the wing effect became popular by the1950s.''
  • ''Lashes – extended the barriers of the eye to appear slightly larger.''
    • *''Blush – pastel and rose colors applied to the apple of the cheek.''
    • ''Lips –'' vibrant red and matte color, applied to look plumper.{{Cite book|title=Fashions in Makeup: From Ancient to Modern Times|last=Corson|first=Richard|publisher=Peter Owens Publisher|year=2005|isbn=0720611954|location=London, United Kingdom|pages=}}
    In the 1950s, the overall look was the red lip was often matched with rosie cheeks. Eyeliner became bold and made a widening effect to make the eye appear larger. Natural eyebrows were embraced as opposed to the thin brows of the 1920s and 30s. 1940s brows were shaped and clean but filled in with a pencil to appear fuller.“Historial Facts Behind Pin Up Makeup.” ''Historial Facts Behind Pin Up Makeup - RebelCircus.com'', 10 Dec. 2014, www.rebelcircus.com/blog/historical-facts-behind-pin-makeup/full/. Lipstick "turned into a symbol of resilient femininity in the face of danger"{{Cite journal|last=Schaffer|first=Sarah|date=2006|title=Reading Our Lips: The History of Lipstick Regulation in Western Seats of Power|url=https://dash.harvard.edu/bitstream/handle/1/10018966/schaffer06.pdf?sequence=1|journal=Food & Drug|volume=|pages=165–225|via=HeinOnline}} and was seen as a way to boost morale during the war. The shape of the lip was also iconic of the 1940s. The lips were painted on to look plumper, a broad outline of the lip was added for roundness. This fuller look is known as the "Hunter’s Bow", invented by [[Max Factor]].{{Cite book|title=Max Factor and Hollywood: A Glamorous History|last=Thomas|first=Erika|publisher=History Press|year=2016|isbn=1467136107|location=United States|pages=}} The pin curl is a staple of the pin-up style, "women utilized pin curls for their main hair curling technique".{{Cite web|url=http://www.vintagehairstyling.com/bobbypinblog/2017/07/demystifying-pin-curls.html|title=Demystifying Pin Curls {{!}} Bobby Pin Blog / Vintage hair and makeup tips and tutorials|website=www.vintagehairstyling.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-08}} Originating in the 1920s from the "water-waving technique", the hair style of the 1940s consisted of a fuller, gentle curl. The drying technique consists of curling a damp piece of hair, from the end to the root and pin in place. Once the curl is dry, it is brushed through to create the desired soft curl, with a voluminous silhouette. [[Victory rolls]] are also a distinctive hairstyle of the pin-up. The Victory roll is curled inward and swept off the face and pinned into place on the top of the head. Soft curls, achieved through the pin curl technique, finish off the look of pin-up.{{Cite news|url=https://www.babble.com/beauty/victory-rolls-pin-up-tutorial/|title=Victory Rolls: A Pin-Up Hair Tutorial {{!}} Babble|date=2013-10-10|work=Babble|access-date=2018-05-08|language=en-US}} As a makeup style, the classic pin-up underwent a revival in modern fashion. The red lip and winged eyeliner made a re-emergence in 2010, with singer, [[Katy Perry]] being the most accessible example of modern pin-up makeup. There is a lack of representation in the media of women of color as pin-up models, even though they were influential to the construction of the style and were just as glamorous.{{Citation|last=As/Is|title=Women Of Color Get Transformed Into Pinups|date=2016-06-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BiMOXaE8K7U|accessdate=2018-05-08}} As a makeup style, it is simple and sleek makeup, that is noticeable and glamorous. == Pin-up in the contemporary age == Although pin-up modeling is associated with World War II and the 1950s, it has developed more recently into a subculture which can be seen represented in the styles of some celebrities and public figures. [[Pamela Anderson]] was considered the "perennial pin-up" due to decades worth of modeling for [[Hugh Hefner]]'s [[Playboy magazine|Playboy Magazine]].{{cite newspaper|last=Kercher|first=Sophia|title=From Pinup to Muse: Pamela Anderson’s Next Chapter|newspaper=The New York Times|date=8 March 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/10/fashion/from-pinup-to-muse-pamela-andersons-next-chapter.html}} The American singer [[Lana Del Rey]], whose style is comparable to that of the classic pin-up model, has performed a song called "Pin Up Galore".{{Cite AV media|title=Pin Up Galore (Live)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jgYno78wUIE|via=YouTube|date=24 April 2012}} [[Beyoncé]] has recorded a song titled "Why Don’t You Love Me"{{Cite AV media|title=Beyoncé - Why Don't You Love Me|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QczgvUDskk0|via=YouTube|date=18 May 2010}} which pays tribute to the pin-up queen of the 1950s, Bettie Page. The burlesque performer [[Dita Von Teese]] is often referred to as a modern pin-up. She has appeared in a biographical film about Bettie Page, "Bettie Page Reveals All,"{{cite web|title=Bettie Page Reveals All (2012)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1776086/|website=IMDb}} in which Von Teese helps to define pin-up. [[Katy Perry]] makes use of the ideas associated with pin-up modeling, and has included these in music videos and costumes. The [[Victoria's Secret Fashion Show]] can be comparable to burlesque show, whereas their yearly advent calendar can compare to pin-up in general. {{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/27/style/victorias-secret-fashion-show-love-advent-weinstein.html|title=Pinups in the Post-Weinstein World|access-date=2018-11-25|language=en}} The pin-up modeling subculture has produced magazines and forums dedicated to its community. "Delicious Dolls",{{Cite web|url=http://deliciousdollsmagazine.com/about-us/.|title=About Delicious Dolls Magazine & Retro Pinup Models|last=|first=|date=|website=Delicious Dolls Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} a magazine that began in 2011 and has both a print and digital version, was described in 2015 as "the most-liked" pin-up magazine in the world. One of the magazine's mission statements is "to promote and showcase retro and modern pin up girls". The magazine supports pin-up-related events throughout the United States and allows anyone to be featured in the magazine as long as they have worked with an approved photographer. Within this subculture there are opportunities to perform in pin-up contests, including one which takes place during the Viva Las Vegas [[rockabilly]] festival.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vivalasvegas.net/pin-up-contest/.|title=Viva Las Vegas: Pin Up Contest|last=|first=|date=|website=Viva Las Vegas|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The goal of the contest is "not one that is based solely on popularity or cosmetic appeal, but one that includes inner beauty as well". Women of "all shapes and sizes" are encouraged to participate, and winners are judged on their biographies, pastimes, and work they do outside of the pin-up hobby. They do not perform, but rather are judged on their authenticity, originality, overall styling presentation, crowd appeal, and stage presence. == Women of color in pin-up == [[File:Baker Banana.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Josephine Baker]] in a banana skirt from the Folies Bergère production ''Un Vent de Folie'', 1927]] Though [[Marilyn Monroe in popular culture|Marilyn Monroe]] and [[Bettie Page]] are often cited as the classic pin-up, there were many women of color who were also considered to be impactful. In the 1920s two of the most notable Black burlesque dancers were [[Josephine Baker]] and [[Lottie 'The Body' Graves|Lottie Graves]]. Despite the little history on Black burlesque dancers, Josephine Baker and Lottie Graves are a good starting point for evaluating women of color in pin-up. [[Dorothy Dandridge]] and [[Eartha Kitt]] also added to the pin-up style of their time, using their looks, fame, and personal success. African-American pin-up finally had a platform when the magazine, [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]], was created in 1951. Jet supported pin-up as they had a full page feature called, "Beauty of the Week", where African-American women posed in a swimsuits and such. This was intended to showcase the beauty these women possessed as they lived in a world where their skin color was under constant scrutiny. It was not until 1965 that [[Jennifer Jackson (model)|Jennifer Jackson]] became the first African American to be published in ''[[Playboy]]'' as Playmate of the Month. And it was not until 1990 that ''Playboy''’s Playmate of the Year was an African-American woman, [[Renee Tenison|Renee Tennison]]. Historically, women of color in pin-up are still not as common as their white counterparts. However, the recent revival of pin-up style has propelled many women of color today to create and dabble with the classic pin-up look to create their own standards of beauty. In Jim Linderman’s self-published book, "Secret History of the Black Pin Up",{{Cite book|title=Secret History of the Black Pin Up: Women of Color from Pin Up to Porn|last=Linderman|first=Jim|publisher=Dull Tool Dim Bulb Books|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=}} he describes the lives and experiences of African-American pin-up models. ==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Bad girl art]] * [[Bombshell (sex symbol)]] {{nb10}} * [[Glamour photography]] * [[Good girl art]] * [[Gravure idol]] * [[Irving Klaw]] * [[List of pin-up artists]] * [[Nose art]] * [[Page three girl]] * [[Sweater girl]] *[[Alberto Vargas]] }} ==References== '''Notes''' {{notelist|notes=}} '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}} '''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |title=Movers and shakers: a chronology of words that shaped our age |first=John |last=Ayto |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2006 |isbn=0-19-861452-7 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |title=Pin-up grrrls: feminism, sexuality, popular culture |first=Maria Elena |last=Buszek |publisher=[[Duke University Press]] |year=2006 |isbn=0-8223-3746-0 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |last=Meyerowitz |first=Joanne |title=Women, Cheesecake, and Borderline Material |journal=Journal of Women's History |volume=8 |issue=3 |year=1996 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Ross |first=Andrew |title=No Respect: Intellectuals and Popular Culture |year=1989 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-90036-0 |ref=harv}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Pin-up-art}} *[http://www.theweek.co.uk/pictures/30411/50-years-us-pin-ups 50 Years of American Pin-Ups] – slideshow by The Week UK *[http://www.thepinupmag.com The Pin Up] – The Pin Up Magazine for more information on Pin Up Girls from 2000s {{DEFAULTSORT:Pin-Up Girl}} [[Category:Celebrity fandom]] [[Category:Modeling]] [[Category:Pin-up art]] [[Category:Stereotypes of women]] [[Category:Fashion]]

{{italic title}} [[File:SKROCKRGRL.jpg|thumb|Issue #10 ''ROCKRGRL'' featuring [[Sleater-Kinney]] ]] '''''ROCKRGRL''''' was the first national publication for female musicians in the United States. Created by [[Carla DeSantis Black|Carla DeSantis]], the magazine purely focused on women in music and highlighted the artistic diversity of women musicians, often overlooked in mainstream culture. The magazine ran for eleven years, and the strength of its message inspired two pioneering ''ROCKRGRL'' conferences that showcased, celebrated, and addressed the state of the music industry for female artists. In December 2008, the ROCKRGRL Magazine and conference archives were acquired by [[Schlesinger Library]] at the [[Radcliffe Institute]], Harvard University, to be included in their collection of American Women’s History artifacts.Brodeur, Nicole.[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nicolebrodeur/2008674654_brodeur27m.html “ROCKRGRL to Play On at Harvard”] January 27, 2009. ==''ROCKRGRL'' magazine== ===History=== ''ROCKRGRL'' was started by Carla DeSantis (aka Carla DeSantis Black) in 1994 in [[San Mateo, California]] as part of the [[zine]] movement to provide a [[third-wave feminist]] perspective on women in music. Commenting on the magazine’s founding, DeSantis recalled, “One issue of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' was about Women Who Rock, and the writer asked everyone what their favorite perfume was, not music. Women were really shut out of music magazines like they didn’t exist.”[https://www.scribd.com/doc/57424003/Interview-With-Carla-DeSantis-Black "Interview with Carla DeSantis Black"] June 2, 2011. ''ROCKRGRL'' started out as a 14-page, black-and-white photocopied zine. Its first issue, which hit stands in 1995, featured Gretchen Seager on the cover along with articles about [[that dog.]], [[the Go-Go's]], [[Queen Latifah]], and [[Au Pairs (band)|Au Pairs]]. In 1999, ''ROCKRGRL'' became a full-color glossy bi-monthly magazine.McCann, Chris.[http://www.nadamucho.com/features/interviews/carla_desantis_-_nada_talks_with_the_rockrgrl.html "Carla DeSantis - Nada Talks With THE ROCKRGRL"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928154123/http://www.nadamucho.com/features/interviews/carla_desantis_-_nada_talks_with_the_rockrgrl.html |date=2007-09-28 }} Nada Mucho.com feature, November 10, 2005. Throughout its lifespan, many famous and influential women appeared on the cover, including [[Justine Frischmann]], [[Shirley Manson]], [[Veruca Salt (band)|Veruca Salt]], [[Tori Amos]], [[Johnette Napolitano]], [[Courtney Love]], [[Kathleen Hanna]], [[Joan Jett]], [[Kat Bjelland]], [[Samantha Maloney]], [[Tegan and Sara]], [[Jessicka]], [[Aimee Mann]], [[Sleater-Kinney]] and [[Marianne Faithfull]]. In the fall of 2005, DeSantis announced that issue number 57 would be the final issue of ''ROCKRGRL''. Although single issues, merchandise and Discoveries CDs could be purchased through the site, they were no longer accepting subscriptions. However, full sets, all 57 issues of ROCKRGRL are now part of the collection at [[The Smithsonian]] in Washington, D.C. and other prestigious colleges and institutions including Harvard, Duke, Cornell, UCLA, University of Washington, Radcliffe Institute, Smith, Oberlin, Rutgers, University of Texas Austin, the New York Public Library. ===Mission=== ''ROCKRGRL'' billed itself as, "a real departure from the condescending and patronizing tone found in other "women in music" magazines and web sites. No beauty tips or guilt trips here — just shop talk with fascinating artists." From its inception, ''ROCKRGRL'' created an atmosphere for women to address music industry sexism head-on. Here is an example from Gretchen Seager of Mary's Danish who appeared on the magazine's first cover: {{quote|text=I don’t want to be qualified as a female singer. I just want to be a singer. And I don’t think you should be qualified by your gender. That’s always bullshit. And unfortunately, it’s probably not going to change in my lifetime. But I just want to be considered a good lyricist and a good singer, not a “girl” singer or a “girl” lyricist. That’s not relevant. Just evaluate me on my music and my lyrics and I'll be happy.|sign=Gretchen Seager|source=ROCKRGRL Issue #1DeSantis, Carla. [http://carladesantisblack.com/2011/05/10/hello-world/ “Gretchen Seager – ROCKRGRL 1995”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522042249/http://carladesantisblack.com/2011/05/10/hello-world/ |date=2011-05-22 }}}} DeSantis recalled:
So many of the stories that women were able to tell in ROCKRGRL were stories they weren’t able to tell in any place else. What was different about ROCKRGRL was that a lot of the artists we talked to had cautionary tales. My favorite artists to talk to are the ones who can talk honestly about what happened. They were dropped by their label – why did that happen? Bands broke up, why did that happen? In ROCKRGRL, what I was looking for were career arcs and career stories – how people got started, what their career was like, how it went for them, and what unusual things they did to be successful.
===Circulation=== ROCKRGRL peaked at roughly 20,000 in circulation, domestic and international, during the years of 2002 and 2003. The magazine was carried by most major retail chains, including [[Virgin Records]], [[Tower Records]], [[Barnes & Noble]], [[Borders Group|Borders]], and [[Hastings Entertainment]]. ''ROCKRGRL'' could also be found in most [[feminist bookstore]]s. During 2005, the cost for a yearly subscription was $14.95. DeSantis explained:
I wanted ROCKRGRL to be in the hands of musicians. It was important to me that it found women who were playing music.
==Music conferences== DeSantis, one of the nation's leading advocates for women in rock,[http://media.scrippscollege.edu/press-releases/rockrgrl-editor-tackles-activism-women-in-the-music-industry “Rockrgrl Editor Tackles Activism, Women in the Music Industry”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110821062944/http://media.scrippscollege.edu/press-releases/rockrgrl-editor-tackles-activism-women-in-the-music-industry |date=2011-08-21 }} April 4th, 2003. has also produced two highly successful and critically acclaimed ''ROCKRGRL'' Music Conferences which took place in Seattle in 2000 and 2005 respectively.Ascher, Tizzy. [http://pandomag.com/featurestext/rockrgrl.htm “Vive La Grrrl-Style Revolution! ROCKRGRL Women in Music Conference Makes Good on Its Promise of Change Through Unity”] November 8, 2010. [[File:Carla DeSantis 01.jpg|thumb|left]] Based on the business model of [[SXSW]], the goal of the ROCKRGRL Music Conferences was to give women working in the music industry an opportunity to network and allow those who were just starting out an opportunity to meet those who influenced them. With three nights of music showcases featuring female artists in all styles,Cleary, Charlotte.[http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20001103&slug=4051399 “ROCKRGRL Shakes Seattle] a special Woman of ValorEdwards, Margot and Dreilinger, Danielle.[http://www.berklee.edu/news/2007/04/rockrgrl.html “The Pioneers Take a Bow”] April 30, 2007. award dinner, two full days of panels, workshops and an artist-friendly trade show, the ROCKRGRL Music Conferences was an opportunity for women working in music to meet, mix and mingle in the city of Seattle.[http://top40-charts.com/news.php?nid=17513 “Music Legends To Appear at Prestigious Rockrgrl Music Conference @ Seattle”] September 30, 2005. “We had 250 female bands perform in clubs and coffeeshops and all kinds of places in downtown Seattle. We had really A-list artists come and speak and perform. And all levels performed, actually. It was eclectic and interesting. It was a really big deal because for me all the people I admired were in the same room,” said DeSantis. The diverse line-up of speakers and performers at the ROCKRGRL Music Conference included such musical luminaries as [[Patti Smith]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], Courtney Love, [[Ronnie Spector]] ([[The Ronettes]]), [[Amy Ray]] ([[Indigo Girls]]), [[Ann Wilson]], Johnette Napolitano ([[Concrete Blonde]]), [[Kathy Valentine]] ([[The Go-Go's]]), [[Wanda Jackson]], [[The Gossip]], Jessicka ([[Scarling.]] / [[Jack Off Jill]]), [[Exene Cervenka]], [[Eliza Gilkyson]], [[Rosie Flores]], [[Carol Kaye]], [[Wanda Jackson]] and hundreds more. During the 2005 conference, keynote speaker [[Patti Smith]] received the Woman of Valor award on the 30th anniversary of the release of her debut album, ''[[Horses (album)|Horses]]''. The previous recipient of this award was [[Heart (band)|Heart]].Gelber, Linus. [http://musicdish.com/mag/?id=2340can%20 “Seattle's Rockrgrl Music Conference 2000: Out and About in Caffeine City, Dodging Starbucks and Ducking Low-Flying Fish”] November 15, 2000. By 2005, sponsorship for the second ROCKRGRL Music Conference had diminished due emerging economic downturn. Despite this, conference attendance remained high. ===Daisy Rock Guitars=== [[Daisy Rock Guitars]], a subsidiary of [[Schecter Guitars]], is company that makes guitars for girls exclusively. Its first three prototype models debuted in November 2000 at Seattle’s first ''ROCKRGRL'' Conference. ==Cultural impact== ''ROCKRGRL'' Magazine has been lauded in feature articles in ''[[The LA Times]]'', ''[[New York Times]]'', [[Seventeen (American magazine)|''Seventeen'']], ''[[Jane (magazine)|Jane]]'', ''[[Seattle Times]]'', ''Mercer Island Reporter'', ''[[Village Voice]]'', ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', ''Boston Rock'', ''[[Asbury Park Press]]'', ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]'', [[Bitch (magazine)|''Bitch'']], and [[Bust (magazine)|''Bust'']].[http://www.carladesantis.net Carla DeSantis bio], April 20, 2006 DeSantis furthers:
Women’s voices have been repressed for many years in music. Most of the pop stars we see are singing songs written by men, or written for them. My day, in the 80’s, there were lots of women in music who were writing their own material...What the magazine provided was an opportunity for women who weren’t only singers to find their voices through the magazine. When there aren’t many women doing something, it’s hard to have them as role models. Different ages, different styles of music – they demonstrate that women have a lot to say, and because mainstream music magazines weren’t exploring that, it needed to be explored in some way. The more we see woman musicians, the less of a novelty they will be.
A ‘’ROCKRGRL Day’’ was held at Musicians’ Institute in Los Angeles in 2003. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.carlablackatx.com Carla DeSantis Black's Official Website] *[http://www.meowonline.wordpress.com Musicians for Equal Opportunities for Women] [[Category:Cultural magazines]] [[Category:Third-wave feminism]] [[Category:Defunct women's magazines of the United States]] [[Category:American music magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1994]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 2005]] [[Category:Rock festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Music conferences]] [[Category:Feminist magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in California]] [[Category:Women's festivals]] [[Category:1994 establishments in California]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use British English|date=August 2012}} {{cleanup|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox television| | show_name = S Club 7 Go Wild! | image = SClub7GoWildtitles.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = ''S Club 7 Go Wild!'' opening titles | opentheme = "[[Never Had a Dream Come True]]" | runtime = 30 minutes | producer = | num_episodes = 7 | num_seasons = 1 | starring = [[S Club|S Club 7]] | country = United Kingdom | network = [[BBC Two]] | first_aired = 25 September 2000 | last_aired = 6 November 2000 }}
'''''S Club 7 Go Wild!''''' was a television series starring British [[pop music|pop]] group [[S Club|S Club 7]], who teamed up with the [[World Wild Fund for Nature]] (WWF) to help raise awareness of the threats facing wildlife around the world. Each member adopted an endangered animal and travelled to their respective natural habitat in different locations around the globe. There were seven 30-minute episodes, one for each member of the band, which were aired on [[CBBC]] in the UK.
==Episode 1==
===Paul in Kenya===
[[Paul Cattermole]] travelled to [[Kenya]] in search of the endangered [[black rhino]] with [[Rachel Stevens]].
'''Day 1:''' Paul went in search of the black rhino. He was unsuccessful, but he did see cheetah cubs. Rachel went shopping in the market for presents for the rest of the group.
'''Day 2:''' Paul travelled to [[Masai Mara]] with Rachel. There he had a game drive, and showed the tribe some dance moves with Rachel.
'''Day 3:''' When Paul went to bed, he could hear all the animal noises; he found it very frightening.
'''Day 4:''' Paul went hot air ballooning with Rachel. They got to see the [[wildebeest]] migration. Later that day, he continued his hunt, and saw a black rhino.
'''Day 5:''' Paul and Rachel went on a river cruise and saw hippos and fish eagles. Then they started their return to the United Kingdom.
==Episode 2==
===Jo in Thailand=== [[Jo O'Meara]] travelled to [[Thailand]] in search of the [[Asian elephant]], accompanied by [[Jon Lee (singer)|Jon Lee]] and [[Tina Barrett]].
'''Day 1:''' Jo, Jon, and Tina spent the day shopping for presents and traditional Thai outfits in Chiang Mai.
'''Day 2:''' Jo travelled to a WWF project, where she saw some Asian elephants. She trekked into the jungle with an elephant to a Thai hill tribe.
'''Day 3:''' Jo spent the day at the Thailand Elephant Conservation Centre. This was their last day in Thailand.
==Episode 3==
===Bradley in Brazil=== [[Bradley McIntosh]] travelled to [[Brazil]] in search of the rare [[hyacinth macaw]]. [[Hannah Spearritt]] accompanied him.
'''Day 1:''' Bradley took a helicopter ride over [[Rio de Janeiro]]. Hannah took the tram up to see the statue of Christ.
'''Day 2:''' Bradley flew to [[Sao Paulo]] to see a World Cup qualifying match between Brazil and [[Argentina]].
'''Day 3:''' Bradley traveled into the jungle with Hannah.
'''Day 4:''' Bradley and Hannah found a nesting pair of hyacinth macaws. That night, they went looking for crocodiles.
'''Day 5:''' Bradley and Hannah spent the day feeding the animals at a ranch.
==Episode 4==
===Tina in China=== [[Tina Barrett]] travelled to China in search of the [[giant panda]] with Jo O'Meara and Jon Lee.
'''Day 1:''' Tina went to see the [[Great Wall of China]]. As the group walked along the wall, they gave facts about the history of the famous landmark.
'''Day 2:''' Tina did karaoke and went ten pin bowling.
'''Day 3:''' Tina got to see some of the remaining giant pandas.
'''Day 4:''' Tina, Jon, and Jo trekked up [[Mount Emei]] to see a panoramic view of China. They stayed there to watch the sunrise. This was their last day in China.
==Episode 5==
===Hannah in Turkey=== [[Hannah Spearritt]] traveled to [[Turkey]] to find the [[monk seal]] with Bradley McIntosh.
'''Day 1:''' Hannah went shopping in [[Istanbul]] for Bradley's birthday.
'''Day 2:''' Hannah went for a camel trek.
'''Day 3:''' Hannah and Bradley went fishing with some Turkish fishermen.
'''Day 4:''' Hannah went scuba diving with Bradley, but did not see a monk seal.
'''Day 5:''' Hannah went jet-skiing, but was disheartened after still not finding a seal.
==Episode 6==
===Rachel in Russia=== [[Rachel Stevens]] traveled to [[Russia]] searching for the [[Siberian tiger]] with Paul Cattermole.
'''Day 1:''' Rachel and Paul spent the day traveling across Russia, starting in Moscow.
'''Day 2:''' Rachel had a tour of [[Vladivostok]]. Rachel made a stop at a museum to learn more about the Siberian tiger.
'''Day 3:''' Rachel joined up with some WWF staff. They found a tiger footprint. Rachel learned about [[poaching]]. Paul was stuck with finding them suitable accommodations for their stay.
'''Day 4:''' Rachel and Paul saw a family of five tigers.
'''Day 5:''' Rachel and Paul went to the Vladivostok Beach and began their return to the UK.
==Episode 7==
===Jon in Malaysia=== [[Jon Lee (singer)|Jon Lee]], Tina Barrett, and Jo O'Meara traveled to Malaysia in search of the [[orangutan]].
'''Day 1:''' Jon, Tina, and Jo traveled to Borneo, where they went to a bat cave to get "dinner". They went to the [[Monsopiad Cultural Village]], which was home to the [[Kadazan]] Warrior. There they saw 39 human skulls.
'''Day 2:''' Jon took a boat trip in the rain, where he saw some orangutans from the river. Jon was able to see a water snake and some elephants. Jo and Tina went to an island to find sea turtles and went snorkeling. Jo and Tina helped day-old sea turtles into the sea.
'''Day 3:''' Tina and Jo flew by helicopter to meet Jon. They went to an orangutan center and got to meet the animals face to face.
== Video/DVD Releases == Not only was Go Wild! released on VHS but unlike all the other S Club 7 TV Shows, this one was released on DVD making Go Wild! the only S Club 7 show to get a DVD release.
== External links == * {{tv.com show|s-club-7|S Club 7 Go Wild!}}
{{S Club 7}}

revision.comment: There is no such language as "Kenyan". Many languages are spoken there.
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=April 2011}} '''Shisima''' is a two-player [[abstract strategy game]] from [[Kenya]]. It is related to [[tic-tac-toe]], and even more so to [[Three Men's Morris]], [[Nine Holes]], [[Achi (game)|Achi]], [[Tant Fant]], and [[Dara (game)|Dara]], because pieces are moved on the board to create the 3-in-a-row. Unlike those other games, Shisima uses an octagonal board.
''Shisima'' means "body of water" in some language spoken in Kenya. The pieces are called ''imbalavali'' which translates to "water bugs" as the pieces move quickly on the board as [[Heteroptera#"Waterbug"|water bugs]] do on the surface of a lake.
== Goal ==
To create a ''3-in-a-row'' of one's pieces running through the middle of the octagonal board.
== Equipment ==
An octagonal board is used. Lines connect each corner of the octagon to its opposite corner. The eight lines intersect at the middle of the octagonal board. There is a total of 9 intersection points or spaces for pieces to be played at.
Each player has 3 pieces. One plays the black pieces, and the other plays the white pieces, however, any two colors or small objects will suffice.
The board is easily drawn on the ground, cardboard, or paper.
== Rules and gameplay ==
1. Players decide what colors to play, and who will start first.
2. Each player's three pieces are initially next to each other in a row on the perimeter points of the octagon facing opposite the other player's three pieces which are also next to each other in a row on the perimeter of the octagon. This leaves three empty spaces left. One empty space is the middle of the board. The other two empty spaces separate the two rows of pieces on both sides.
3. Each piece can move one space at a time following the pattern on the board. Only one piece can be moved per turn.
4. Repeating a position three times is a draw.
== Related games == * [[Achi (game)|Achi]] * [[Dara (game)]] * [[Nine Holes]] * [[Picaria]] * [[Tant Fant]] * [[Three Men's Morris]] * [[tic-tac-toe]]
== External links == * http://www.kruzno.com/Shisima.html * http://healthy.uwaterloo.ca/museum/VirtualExhibits/rowgames/shisima.html
[[Category:Abstract strategy games]] [[Category:Traditional board games]] [[Category:Kenyan culture]] [[Category:African games]] [[Category:In-a-row games]]

{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Soggade Chinni Nayana | image = Soggade Chinni Nayana poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = Kalyan Krishna Kurasala | producer = [[Akkineni Nagarjuna]] | screenplay = [[Ram Mohan P]] | story = Ram Mohan P | starring = Akkineni Nagarjuna
[[Ramya Krishnan]]
[[Lavanya Tripathi]] | music = [[Anup Rubens]] | cinematography = [[P. S. Vinod]]
Siddhardh Ramaswami | editing = [[Prawin Pudi]] | studio = [[Annapurna Studios]] | distributor = Annapurna Studios | released = {{Film date|df=y|2016|1|15}} | runtime = 145 minutes | country = India | language = Telugu | budget = {{INR}}150{{ndash}}200 million{{efn|The [[Broadsheet|broadsheet newspaper]] ''[[Daily News and Analysis]]'' estimates the film's budget as {{INR}}150 million,{{cite web | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-nagarjuna-s-soggade-chinni-nayana-sequel-is-on-the-cards-2181637 | title=Nagarjuna's 'Soggade Chinni Nayana' sequel is on the cards | work=[[Daily News and Analysis]] | date=24 February 2016 | accessdate=24 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160224125848/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-nagarjuna-s-soggade-chinni-nayana-sequel-is-on-the-cards-2181637 | archivedate=24 February 2016}} and the online news website [[International Business Times|International Business Times India]] estimates the film's budget as {{INR}}200 million.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nagarjuna-registers-title-bangarraju-sequel-soggade-chinni-nayana-668124 | title=Nagarjuna registers title 'Bangarraju' as sequel to 'Soggade Chinni Nayana' | work=[[International Business Times|International Business Times India]] | date=24 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160224132111/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nagarjuna-registers-title-bangarraju-sequel-soggade-chinni-nayana-668124 | archivedate=24 February 2016}}|name="budget"}} | gross = {{INR}}750 million }} '''''Soggade Chinni Nayana''''' ({{lang-en|The Young Man is a Charmer|italic=yes}}) is a 2016 Indian [[Telugu language|Telugu-language]] [[Supernatural fiction|supernatural]] [[Drama (genre)|drama film]] directed by Kalyan Krishna Kurasala. In addition to producing the film under his [[Annapurna Studios]] banner, [[Akkineni Nagarjuna]] played dual roles. [[Ramya Krishnan]] and [[Lavanya Tripathi]] were the film's female leads. [[Nassar]], [[Pithamagan Mahadevan]], [[Sampath Raj]] and [[Brahmanandam]] played key supporting roles. Written by [[Ram Mohan P]], ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' revolves around the soul of Bangarraju, a flirtatious [[zamindar]] whom [[Yama]] (the god of the underworld) sends back to earth to reconcile his son (Ram "Ramu" Mohan) and his wife Seetha; they are on the brink of divorce. In the process, he learns about his death and its connection with a local [[Shiva]] temple. [[P. S. Vinod]] and Siddhardh Ramaswami provided the cinematography, and [[Anup Rubens]] composed the film's soundtrack and background score. [[Prawin Pudi]] edited the film. [[Principal photography]] for the film began on 19 November 2014 after it was launched in [[Hyderabad]], and wrapped on 4 October 2015. Most of the film was shot in and around [[Rajahmundry]] and [[Mysore]]. Produced on a budget of {{INR}}150{{ndash}}200 million, ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' was released worldwide on 15 January 2016 during the [[Makar Sankranti]] festival season in 800-900 screens. It received positive reviews from critics and was commercially successful, earning {{INR}}750 million globally. The film was remade in [[Kannada]] as ''[[Upendra Matte Baa]]'' (2017), starring [[Upendra (actor)|Upendra]], [[Prema (actress)|Prema]] and [[Sruthi Hariharan]] in the lead roles. == Plot == Ram "Ramu" Mohan is a socially-inept [[cardiologist]] practicing in the [[United States]]. His wife, Seetha, feels lonely since Ramu pays very little attention to her because of his work. They decide to divorce and leave for Sivapuram, [[Rajahmundry]], where Ramu's mother Satyabhama lives. Satyabhama, shocked to learn that Ramu and Seetha are divorcing, shouts at a portrait of her deceased husband Bangarraju (a benevolent, flirtatious zamindar who died nearly 30 years ago in an accident). Bangarraju's soul is in [[Naraka (Hinduism)|Naraka]], where he continues to flirt. [[Yama]], at [[Shiva]]'s command, sends him back to earth because there is a mission only he can fulfil. Bangarraju, who can be seen and heard only by Satyabhama, tries to solve his family's problems. After several unsuccessful attempts, Bangarraju possesses Ramu's body on his birthday. He meets Ramu's young female cousins, and invites them to his home. On his way back Ramu meets Suri, a frightened drunk who runs away as Ramu and Bangarraju look identical. To free himself from guilt, Suri later admits that he murdered Bangarraju with a lorry after he was bribed. Before he can disclose more details, Suri dies in an accident and Bangarraju learns that his family is in danger. Ramu spends quality time with his cousins, making Seetha jealous. Bangarraju is confronted by Satyabhama, who is unaware of recent events. He suggests that she help Seetha impress Ramu. At Satyabhama's suggestion, Ramu and Seetha go to a theatre to watch a film. When she is taunted, Ramu (possessed by Bangarraju) overpowers her tormenters. Seetha is pleasantly surprised, since Ramu failed to confront the same group earlier in a similar situation. The couple slowly grow closer, and Seetha realises that Ramu does love her. Bangarraju learns from Athmanandam, a [[Godman (India)|godman]] who can communicate with souls, that his uncle Rudraraju masterminded his murder. Rudraraju and his cousin, Veerababu, wanted to steal jewellery from a 1,000-year old temple to [[Shiva]]. They murdered Bangarraju, bribing Suri to silence him. After Rudraraju's son dies when he is bitten by a divine snake, a [[tantra|tantrik]] warns that only Bangarraju's descendants can open the lock; others would be killed by the snake. The tantrik captures Bangarraju's soul and gives a few threads to Sampath, Rudraraju's grandson, telling him to tie them to the hands of every member of Bangarraju's family to keep his soul from communicating with them. After Sampath and the others leave, the snake kills the tantrik and saves Bangarraju's soul. Bangarraju reaches the temple, where Satyabhama can neither see nor hear him and he cannot possess Ramu. Rudraraju and Sampath attack Ramu and Seetha after the jewellery is removed from the treasury. Rudraraju tells his henchmen to put the couple in a car with the jewellery, which will make the villagers think that they are the thieves. The thread to Ramu's hand comes loose, and Bangarraju possesses him. Bangarraju fights them and retrieves the jewellery before leaving Ramu, who operates on an injured Seetha in a nearby hospital. Satyabhama removes the thread and can see Bangarraju. Ramu and Seetha reconcile, and Yama orders Bangarraju to come back in accordance with Shiva's instructions. When Satyabhama begs Bangarraju to stay, Yama gives him a chance to wipe away her tears. He asks her to keep smiling and live happily for his sake, and returns to Naraka. == Cast == {{Div col}} * [[Akkineni Nagarjuna]] as Bangarraju and Ram "Ramu" Mohan * [[Ramya Krishna]] as Satyabhama * [[Lavanya Tripathi]] as Seetha * [[Nassar]] as Rudraraju * [[Pithamagan Mahadevan]] as Veerababu * [[Sampath Raj]] as Sampath * [[Brahmanandam]] as Athmanandam * [[Nagendra Babu]] as [[Yama (Hinduism)|Yama]] * [[Duvvasi Mohan]] as [[Chitragupta]] * [[Posani Krishna Murali]] as Suri * [[Chalapathi Rao]] as Chalapathi * [[Brahmaji]] as Ramu's cousin * [[Vennela Kishore]] as Ramu's cousin * Jhansi as Saraswathi * [[Banerjee (actor)|Banerjee]] as Sampath's father * [[Hamsa Nandini]] as Hamsa * [[Anasuya Bharadwaj]] as Bujji * [[Saptagiri (Telugu actor)|Saptagiri]] as Himagiri * [[L. B. Sriram]] as the temple priest * [[Anushka Shetty]] as Krishna Kumari ([[cameo appearance]]) * [[Diksha Panth]] as Hamsa's sister (cameo appearance) {{Div col end}} == Production == {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | footer = ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' is the eighth collaboration between Akkineni Nagarjuna (''left'') and Ramya Krishnan, and Nagarjuna's 92nd film as an actor.{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/tollywood/160116/save-the-girl-now-world-later-nagarjuna.html |title=Save the girl now, world later: Nagarjuna |work=[[Deccan Chronicle]] |date=17 January 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |last=K. Jha |first=Subhash |authorlink=Subhash K. Jha |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923165014/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/tollywood/160116/save-the-girl-now-world-later-nagarjuna.html |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} | width = | image1 = Nagarjuna at 62nd Filmfare awards south.jpg | width1 = 153 | alt1 = Man in a grey suit poses for the camera. | caption1 = | image2 = Ramya Krishnan.jpg | width2 = 150 | alt2 = Woman in pink looks away from the camera. | caption2 = }} During the production of ''[[Manam (film)|Manam]]'' (2014), producer and lead actor [[Akkineni Nagarjuna]] liked the portions which were set against a village backdrop. He developed an interest in making a film based on Indian village life, feeling that audiences would see a "new, yet traditional lifestyle, something fresh and interesting".{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/interview-soggade-chinni-nayana-will-see-me-explore-a-village-subject-after-a-decade-says-nagarjuna-2165270 |title='Soggade Chinni Nayana' will see me explore a village subject after a decade, says Nagarjuna |work=Daily News and Analysis |date=13 January 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |last=Srinivasan |first=Latha |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923143934/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/interview-soggade-chinni-nayana-will-see-me-explore-a-village-subject-after-a-decade-says-nagarjuna-2165270 |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} After sketching the basic idea, [[Ram Mohan P]] approached Virinchi Varma to direct the film; Mohan produced Varma's directorial debut, ''[[Uyyala Jampala]]'' (2013). Varma declined the offer, since he wanted to film his own script.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehansindia.com/posts/index/Cinema/2016-09-23/Ram-Mohan-asked-me-to-direct-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana/255276 |title=Ram Mohan asked me to direct ‘Soggade Chinni Nayana’ |work=[[The Hans India]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |last=Goud |first=Nagaraj |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923145120/http://www.thehansindia.com/posts/index/Cinema/2016-09-23/Ram-Mohan-asked-me-to-direct-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana/255276 |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nagarjuna then gave the synopsis to Kalyan Krishna Kurasala, who completed the script within a month. Kurasala was confirmed as director, marking his directorial debut in Telugu cinema.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/i-want-to-make-good-fun-films-actor-nagarjuna/article8085690.ece |title=‘I want to make good, fun films’ |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=9 January 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |last=Dundoo |first=Sangeetha Devi |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923164747/http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/i-want-to-make-good-fun-films-actor-nagarjuna/article8085690.ece |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nagarjuna approved the inclusion of supernatural elements, such as the ghost of Bangarraju and the divine snake guarding his family, on the condition that they be positive and not frightening. He played two roles: Bangarraju, a flirtatious zamindar, and his son Ramu (a socially-inept doctor, born the day after Bangarraju's death). Ramu's character was based on Umakanth, a contestant on ''[[Meelo Evaru Koteeswarudu]]'' (a game show hosted by Nagarjuna). As Bangarraju, Nagarjuna wore a [[dhoti]] and a 1959 watch; both were worn by his father, [[Akkineni Nageswara Rao]], in his many village-film starring roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151219/entertainment-tollywood/article/akkineni-nageswara-rao-touches-nagarjuna%E2%80%99s-film |title=Akkineni Nageswara Rao touches in Nagarjuna’s film |work=Deccan Chronicle |date=20 December 2015 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923164745/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/151219/entertainment-tollywood/article/akkineni-nageswara-rao-touches-nagarjuna%E2%80%99s-film |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Ramya Krishnan]] and [[Lavanya Tripathi]] were the female leads; [[Pranitha Subhash]] and [[Sonal Chauhan]] were considered before Tripathi was cast.{{cite web | url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/141212/entertainment-tollywood/article/pranitha-subhash-quitting-tollywood | title=Pranitha Subhash quitting Tollywood | work=Deccan Chronicle | date=12 December 2014 | accessdate=14 December 2014 | last=Kavirayani | first=Suresh | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214044709/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/141212/entertainment-tollywood/article/pranitha-subhash-quitting-tollywood | archivedate=14 December 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/141018/entertainment-tollywood/article/nagarjuna-double-role-his-upcoming-film | title=Nagarjuna in double role in his upcoming film | work=Deccan Chronicle | date=18 October 2014 | accessdate=21 November 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141121114538/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/141018/entertainment-tollywood/article/nagarjuna-double-role-his-upcoming-film | archivedate=21 November 2014}} Initially skeptical about playing a married woman, Tripathi agreed after listening to a script reading at the Annapurna Studios office.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/i-was-skeptical-about-playing-a-married-woman/20160115.htm |title='I was skeptical about playing a married woman' |publisher=[[Rediff.com|Rediff]] |date=15 January 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |last=Rajamani |first=Radhika |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923165034/http://www.rediff.com/movies/report/i-was-skeptical-about-playing-a-married-woman/20160115.htm |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In a January 2016 interview with ''[[The Hindu]]'', Nagarjuna mentioned that Bangarraju and Satyabhama (played by Ramya) would be a "hot, romantic" couple, in contrast to the "innocent, cute" Ramu and Seetha (played by Tripathi). After being cast, Tripathi said that her character, a traditional Indian girl, would have a romantic touch.{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjuna-said-I-look-good-onscreen-Lavanya-Tripathi/articleshow/45259445.cms | title=Nagarjuna said I look good onscreen: Lavanya Tripathi | work=[[The Times of India]] | date=24 November 2014 | accessdate=25 November 2014 | last=Sashidhar | first=A. S. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125070147/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjuna-said-I-look-good-onscreen-Lavanya-Tripathi/articleshow/45259445.cms | archivedate=25 November 2014}} L. Satyanand wrote ''Soggade Chinni Nayana''{{'s}} [[screenplay]], and [[Anup Rubens]] composed its soundtrack and score. [[P. S. Vinod]] and Siddhardh Ramaswami were the cinematographers. [[Prawin Pudi]] and Ravinder Reddy were in charge of the film's editing and art direction respectively.{{cite AV media | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana | publisher=[[Annapurna Studios]] | date=2016 | medium=motion picture | location=India | language=Telugu | time=00:05:33 to 00:08:15 | time-caption=From}} A launch ceremony was held on 19 November 2014 at Annapurna Studios in Hyderabad,{{cite web | url=http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/nagarjunas-new-film-launched/article6614405.ece | title=Nagarjuna’s new film launched | work=The Hindu | date=19 November 2014 | agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]] | accessdate=21 November 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141121114649/http://www.thehindu.com/entertainment/nagarjunas-new-film-launched/article6614405.ece | archivedate=21 November 2014}} and [[principal photography]] began several hours later on a set erected in the Studios' premises.{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/nagarjuna-s-new-film-rolls-on-news-telugu-oltr63bhhidag.html | title=Nagarjuna's new film rolls on | publisher=Sify | date=19 November 2014 | accessdate=21 November 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141121114841/http://www.sify.com/movies/nagarjuna-s-new-film-rolls-on-news-telugu-oltr63bhhidag.html | archivedate=21 November 2014}} [[Anushka Shetty]] made a [[cameo appearance]] in the film. [[Hamsa Nandini]] confirmed her inclusion in the cast in December 2014; she played a supporting role and participated in a song with Nagarjuna.{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Hamsa-Nandini-to-star-opp-Nagarjuna/articleshow/45703397.cms | title=Hamsa Nandini to star opp Nagarjuna | work=The Times of India | date=31 December 2014 | accessdate=1 January 2015 | last=Sashidhar | first=A. S. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121065825/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Hamsa-Nandini-to-star-opp-Nagarjuna/articleshow/45703397.cms | archivedate=21 January 2015}} Raju Sundaram, Vishwa and Raghu choreographed the songs. Television presenter [[Anasuya Bharadwaj]] played Nagarjuna's cousin after [[Swati Reddy]] backed out, citing scheduling conflicts.{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Anchor-Anasuya-in-Nagarjunas-film/articleshow/45955130.cms | title=Anchor Anasuya in Nagarjuna's film | work=The Times of India | date=20 January 2015 | accessdate=20 January 2015 | last=Kumar | first=Hemanth | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121065743/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Anchor-Anasuya-in-Nagarjunas-film/articleshow/45955130.cms | archivedate=21 January 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Swathi-turns-down-Nagarjunas-film/articleshow/46025679.cms |title=Swathi turns down Nagarjuna's film |work=The Times of India |date=26 January 2015 |accessdate=27 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127061013/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Swathi-turns-down-Nagarjunas-film/articleshow/46025679.cms |archivedate=27 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Diksha Panth also made a cameo appearance; her inclusion was confirmed in August 2015.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Diksha-Panth-from-sanyasin-to-glam-doll/articleshow/48330682.cms |title=Diksha Panth from sanyasin to glam-doll |work=The Times of India |date=3 August 2015 |accessdate=23 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923165244/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Diksha-Panth-from-sanyasin-to-glam-doll/articleshow/48330682.cms |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nagarjuna had to simultaneously complete his portions of ''[[Oopiri]]'' (2016) and ''Meelo Evaru Koteeswarudu'' during 2015. Filming resumed on 11 February 2015 after completion of two schedules.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjuna-resumes-shooting-for-his-next/articleshow/46140353.cms |title=Nagarjuna resumes shooting for his next |work=The Times of India |date=7 February 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2015
