|archivedate= 7 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Principal photography continued in [[Mysore]] on 10 March 2015 after key sequences were filmed in and around [[Rajahmundry]].{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Soggade-Chinni-Nayana-team-shoots-in-Mysore/articleshow/46514811.cms |title=Soggade Chinni Nayana team shoots in Mysore |work=The Times of India |date=10 March 2015 |accessdate=10 March 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310121149/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Soggade-Chinni-Nayana-team-shoots-in-Mysore/articleshow/46514811.cms |archivedate=10 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Several scenes were filmed at a 1,500-year-old [[Vishnu]] temple in Mysore.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjuna-shoots-at-a-historical-temple/articleshow/46516310.cms |title=Nagarjuna shoots at a historical temple |work=The Times of India |date=10 March 2015 |accessdate=10 March 2015 |last=Kumar |first=Hemanth |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310121327/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjuna-shoots-at-a-historical-temple/articleshow/46516310.cms |archivedate=10 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In September 2015, with ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' nearing completion, its film unit told [[Indo-Asian News Service]] that a few key scenes would be re-filmed on the advice of writer [[Sai Madhav Burra]] (who changed some scenes to suit the story). The re-filming delayed its release.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Key-scenes-of-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana-to-be-reshot/articleshow/49163697.cms |title=Key scenes of Soggade Chinni Nayana to be reshot |work=The Times of India |date=30 September 2015 |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |accessdate=23 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923165251/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Key-scenes-of-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana-to-be-reshot/articleshow/49163697.cms |archivedate=23 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Principal photography [[Wrap (filmmaking)|wrapped]] on 4 October 2015 in Mysore, and [[post-production]] began shortly afterwards.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjunas-wraps-up-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana/articleshow/49216959.cms |title=Nagarjuna’s wraps up Soggade Chinni Nayana |work=The Times of India |date=4 October 2015 |accessdate=24 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924094028/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movies/news/Nagarjunas-wraps-up-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana/articleshow/49216959.cms |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' was produced on a budget of {{INR}}150{{ndash}}200 million.{{efn|name="budget"}} == Release and reception == ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' was released worldwide on 15 January 2016 in 800-900 screens. Three other Telugu films (''[[Nannaku Prematho]]'', ''[[Express Raja]]'' and ''[[Dictator (2016 film)|Dictator]]'') were released at the same time, which affected its distribution.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nannaku-prematho-be-released-more-screens-dictator-soggade-chinni-nayana-express-raja-662180 |title=Nannaku Prematho to be released in more screens than Dictator, Soggade Chinni Nayana, Express Raja |work=International Business Times India |date=6 January 2016 |accessdate=24 September 2016 |last=H. Hooli |first=Shekhar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924101857/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nannaku-prematho-be-released-more-screens-dictator-soggade-chinni-nayana-express-raja-662180 |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Nagarjuna defended his release decision, saying that the film's rural backdrop made it suitable for the [[Makar Sankranti]] season (a harvest festival). He added, "I announced the date two and a half months ago and blocked the theatres. There’s nothing I can do now ..." Global Cinema acquired the film's theatrical rights for the Nizam region.{{efn|For film-industry purposes, the Nizam region includes the three districts of [[Gulbarga district|Gulbarga]], [[Bidar district|Bidar]], and [[Raichur district|Raichur]] in [[Karnataka]] and seven districts in the [[Marathwada]] region ([[Aurangabad district, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]], [[Latur district|Latur]], [[Nanded district|Nanded]], [[Parbhani district|Parbhani]], [[Beed district|Beed]], [[Jalna district|Jalna]] and [[Osmanabad district|Osmanabad]]) apart from the state of [[Telangana]].{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Nizam-territory-will-remain-indispensable-for-Tollywood/articleshow/21499426.cms | title=Nizam territory will remain indispensable for Tollywood | work=The Times of India | date=31 July 2013 | accessdate=24 November 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215082550/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Nizam-territory-will-remain-indispensable-for-Tollywood/articleshow/21499426.cms | archivedate=15 February 2015}}}} === Critical reception === The film received positive reviews from critics.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-review-roundup-critics-call-scn-good-sankranti-treat-family-audience-663533 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana review roundup: Critics call SCN a good Sankranti treat for family audience | work=International Business Times India | date=17 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222134456/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-review-roundup-critics-call-scn-good-sankranti-treat-family-audience-663533 | archivedate=22 February 2016}} Suresh Kavirayani of ''[[Deccan Chronicle]]'' gave ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' four out of five stars, praising Kurasala's narrative clarity and calling it "wonderful overall" for its consistent tempo.{{cite web | url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/movie-reviews/160116/movie-review-soggade-chinni-nayana-it-s-nagarjuna-s-show-all-the-way.html | title=Movie review 'Soggade Chinni Nayana': It’s Nagarjuna’s show all the way! | work=Deccan Chronicle | date=17 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=Kavirayani | first=Suresh | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160221082450/http://deccanchronicle.com/movie-reviews/160116/movie-review-soggade-chinni-nayana-it-s-nagarjuna-s-show-all-the-way.html | archivedate=21 February 2016}} Sangeetha Devi Dundoo, in ''The Hindu'', gave the film 3.5 stars out of five and said it was set in a "familiar, comfort zone" which "guarantees a lot of fun". Dundoo found the temple-and-snake subplot engaging.{{cite web | url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/soggade-chinni-nayana-charms-all-the-way/article8114012.ece | title=‘Soggade’ charms all the way | work=The Hindu | date=16 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=Dundoo | first=Sangeetha Devi | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116115122/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/soggade-chinni-nayana-charms-all-the-way/article8114012.ece | archivedate=16 January 2016}} Pranita Jonnalagedda of ''[[The Times of India]]'' also gave the film 3.5 stars out of five, calling it "so uncomplicated, unfussy and unpretentious" that viewers "get hooked to its simplicity".{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movie-reviews/Soggade-Chinni-Nayana/movie-review/50611004.cms |title=Soggade Chinni Nayana Movie Review |work=The Times of India |date=17 January 2016 |accessdate=22 February 2016 |last=Jonnalagedda |first=Pranitha |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6fUJl2AWM?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/telugu/movie-reviews/Soggade-Chinni-Nayana/movie-review/50611004.cms |archivedate=22 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Sify]] gave ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' three stars out of five, comparing the film to Nageswara Rao's 1978 film ''[[Sri Rama Raksha]]''. The reviewer praised Nagarjuna's performance and Kurasala's narrative clarity.{{cite web | url=http://www.sify.com/movies/soggade-chinni-nayana-review--qbopwUdfiabgc.html | title=Review : Soggade Chinni Nayana | publisher=[[Sify]] | date=16 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130080547/http://www.sify.com/movies/soggade-chinni-nayana-review--qbopwUdfiabgc.html | archivedate=30 January 2016}} L. Ravichander of ''[[The Hans India]]'' gave it a negative review, calling it an obsolete film with crass humor. Ravichander called Ramya's performance the "lone bright spot ... all grace, charm and vigour."{{cite web | url=http://www.thehansindia.com/posts/index/Cinema/2016-01-17/So-obsolete/200626 | title=So... obsolete | work=The Hans India | date=17 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=Ravichander | first=L. | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222135114/http://www.thehansindia.com/posts/index/Cinema/2016-01-17/So-obsolete/200626 | archivedate=22 February 2016}} === Box office === ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' had an average 70-percent theatre occupancy rate and grossed {{INR}}55 million (with a distributor share of {{INR}}39 million) at the [[Andhra Pradesh|AP]]-Nizam box office on its first day. In three days, the film grossed {{INR}}130 million and collected a distributor share of {{INR}}85 million at the AP-Nizam box office. The three-day global gross passed {{INR}}200 million, with a distributor share of {{INR}}141 million.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-3-day-box-office-collection-nagarjunas-scn-turns-2nd-highest-grosser-this-663609 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana 3-day box office collection: Nagarjuna's SCN turns 2nd highest grosser this Sankranti weekend | work=International Business Times India | date=18 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222135536/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-3-day-box-office-collection-nagarjunas-scn-turns-2nd-highest-grosser-this-663609 | archivedate=22 February 2016}} According to trade analyst [[Taran Adarsh]], ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' grossed US$535,183 ({{INR}}362 million) at the United States box office in its first weekend and was Nagarjuna's second-highest-grossing film in India (after ''Manam'').{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-usa-box-office-collection-scn-turns-nagarjuna-2nd-highest-after-manam-663707 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana USA box office collection: SCN turns Nagarjuna's 2nd highest after Manam | work=International Business Times India | date=19 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222135632/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-usa-box-office-collection-scn-turns-nagarjuna-2nd-highest-after-manam-663707 | archivedate=22 February 2016}} In five days, the film grossed $629,303 ({{INR}}42.9 million) at the U.S. box office after a significant decline.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-fares-better-nannaku-prematho-us-box-office-monday-tuesday-663969 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana fares better than Nannaku Prematho at US box office on Monday and Tuesday | work=International Business Times India | date=20 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215212012/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-fares-better-nannaku-prematho-us-box-office-monday-tuesday-663969 | archivedate=15 February 2016}} In its first week, ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' grossed {{INR}}347.4 million globally. With a distributor share of {{INR}}228.3 million, it became profitable.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-express-raja-big-sankranti-hits-nannaku-prematho-dictator-yet-recover-cost-664391 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana, Express Raja big Sankranti hits; Nannaku Prematho, Dictator yet to recover cost | work=International Business Times India | date=24 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201130446/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-express-raja-big-sankranti-hits-nannaku-prematho-dictator-yet-recover-cost-664391 | archivedate=1 February 2016}} After losing 30 screens to ''[[Airlift (film)|Airlift]]'', ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' grossed $776,940 ({{INR}}52.7 million) in ten days at the U.S. box office.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-express-raja-fare-well-us-box-office-2nd-weekend-664709 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana, Express Raja fare well at US box office in 2nd weekend | work=International Business Times India | date=27 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160213142724/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-express-raja-fare-well-us-box-office-2nd-weekend-664709 | archivedate=13 February 2016}} By the end of its second week, the film grossed {{INR}}559.6 million globally and had a distributor share of {{INR}}357.3 million.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-14-day-box-office-collection-nagarjunas-scn-crosses-rs-50-crore-mark-665154 | title='Soggade Chinni Nayana' 14-day box office collection: Nagarjuna's 'SCN' crosses Rs 50 crore mark in 2nd week | work=International Business Times India | date=31 January 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215115212/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-14-day-box-office-collection-nagarjunas-scn-crosses-rs-50-crore-mark-665154 | archivedate=15 February 2016}} In its third week, after losing many screens due to new releases, the film retained 19 screens in the U.S. and grossed $827,918 ({{INR}}53.2 million) in 17 days. With a distributor share of {{INR}}38 million on an investment of {{INR}}6.5 million, ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' became Nagarjuna's highest-grossing film in India.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-us-box-office-collection-scn-fails-cross-1-million-mark-3rd-weekend-665377 | title='Soggade Chinni Nayana' US box office collection: 'SCN' fails to cross $1 million mark in 3rd weekend | work=International Business Times India | date=2 February 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160214141128/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-us-box-office-collection-scn-fails-cross-1-million-mark-3rd-weekend-665377 | archivedate=14 February 2016}} In 20 days, the film grossed {{INR}}638.8 million globally and collected a distributor share of {{INR}}404.8 million; it became one of the few Telugu films to cross the 40-[[crore]] ({{INR}}400 million) mark.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-3rd-week-box-office-collection-nagarjunas-scn-joins-club-rs-40-crore-665730 | title='Soggade Chinni Nayana' 3rd week box office collection: Nagarjuna's 'SCN' joins club of Rs 40 crore movies | work=International Business Times India | date=4 February 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205093244/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-3rd-week-box-office-collection-nagarjunas-scn-joins-club-rs-40-crore-665730 | archivedate=5 February 2016}} ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' retained seven screens in its fourth week in the U.S., grossing $837,089 ({{INR}}56.9 million) in 24 days.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-fares-well-express-raja-hits-rock-bottom-us-box-office-4th-weekend-666250 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana fares well; Express Raja hits rock bottom at US box office in 4th weekend | work=International Business Times India | date=9 February 2016 | accessdate=22 February 2016 | last=H. Hooli | first=Shekhar | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222140016/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-fares-well-express-raja-hits-rock-bottom-us-box-office-4th-weekend-666250 | archivedate=22 February 2016}} The film completed a 50-day-run in more than 75 theatres on 4 March 2016, a record for a Nagarjuna film. The global gross and distributor-share figures stood at {{INR}}700 million and {{INR}}440 million, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-complete-50-days-nagarjunas-scn-collects-rs-70-cr-box-office-669118 |title='Soggade Chinni Nayana' to complete 50 days; Nagarjuna's SCN collects Rs 70 cr at box office |work=International Business Times India |date=2 March 2016 |accessdate=24 September 2016 |last=H. Hooli |first=Shekhar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924170023/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/soggade-chinni-nayana-complete-50-days-nagarjunas-scn-collects-rs-70-cr-box-office-669118 |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} It was estimated to have grossed over {{INR}}750 million globally in its theatrical run.{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/kannada/Kannada-remake-of-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana-on-the-cards/2016/05/26/article3452350.ece |title=Kannada remake of 'Soggade Chinni Nayana' on the cards |work=[[The New Indian Express]] |date=26 May 2016 |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |accessdate=24 September 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924171025/http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/kannada/Kannada-remake-of-Soggade-Chinni-Nayana-on-the-cards/2016/05/26/article3452350.ece |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == Remake == The film was remade in [[Kannada]] as ''[[Upendra Matte Baa]]'' (2017), with [[Upendra (actor)|Upendra]], [[Prema (actress)|Prema]] and [[Sruthi Hariharan]] in the lead roles.{{cite web |url=http://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/upendra-matte-baa-movie-review-soggade-chinni-nayana-remake-works-in-some-bits-falls-flat-in-others-4214999.html |title=Upendra Matte Baa movie review: Soggade Chinni Nayana remake works in some bits, falls flat in others |date=17 November 2017 |website=Firstpost |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20171211151901/http://www.firstpost.com/entertainment/upendra-matte-baa-movie-review-soggade-chinni-nayana-remake-works-in-some-bits-falls-flat-in-others-4214999.html |archivedate=11 December 2017 |accessdate=11 December 2017 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} == Music == {{Infobox album | name = Soggade Chinni Nayana | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Anup Rubens]] | cover = | released = 29th December, 2015 | recorded = 2015 | genre = [[Soundtrack]] | length = 21:39 | label = [[Times Music|Junglee Music]] | producer = Anup Rubens | prev_title = [[Soukhyam]] | prev_year = 2015 | next_title = Padesave | next_year = 2016 }} The six-song ''Soggade Chinni Nayana'' soundtrack was composed by [[Anup Rubens]]; however, its initial release had only five songs. [[Ramajogayya Sastry]] wrote the lyrics for two songs: "Vasthane Vasthane" and "Untale". [[Bhaskarabhatla Ravi Kumar|Bhaskarabhatla]], Balaji and Krishna Kanth wrote the lyrics of one song each.{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iH6S0C0xlH8 | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana Full Songs Jukebox | publisher=[[Aditya Music]] | date=29 December 2015 | accessdate=24 September 2016 | via=[[YouTube]]}} The title song was written by [[Anantha Sreeram]] and performed by Satya Yamini, Nuthana and Vinayak.{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3l7xyiqdvZA | title=Soggade Chinni Nayana Title Song | publisher=Annapurna Studios | date=29 December 2015 | accessdate=24 September 2016 | via=YouTube}} The soundtrack, on [[Aditya Music]], was released on 25 December 2015 with a promotional event at [[Shilpakala Vedika]], Hyderabad.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nagarjunas-soggade-chinni-nayana-audio-launch-live-streaming-watch-scn-music-release-online-660910 |title=Nagarjuna's Soggade Chinni Nayana audio launch live streaming: Watch SCN music release online |work=International Business Times India |date=25 December 2015 |accessdate=24 September 2016 |last=H. Hooli |first=Shekhar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924093422/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/nagarjunas-soggade-chinni-nayana-audio-launch-live-streaming-watch-scn-music-release-online-660910 |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} {{Track listing | collapsed = | headline = Track-List{{cite web |title=Soggade Chinni Nayana (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) - EP by Anup Rubens |url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/soggade-chinni-nayana-original-motion-picture-soundtrack/1071360470 |accessdate=8 November 2018 |language=en-AU |date=29 December 2015}}{{cite web |title=Soggade Chinni Nayana Title Song {{!}}{{!}} Nagarjuna, Ramya Krishnan, Lavanya Tripathi |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VIhcD0B_t6Q |accessdate=8 November 2018 |date=25 December 2015}} | extra_column = Singer(s) | total_length = 21:37 | title1 = Dikka Dikka Dum Dum | lyrics1 = [[Bhaskarabhatla Ravi Kumar]] | extra1 = Akkineni Nagarjuna, Dhanunjay, Mohana Bhogaraju | length1 = 4:07 | title2 = Nee Navve | lyrics2 = Balaji | extra2 = [[Shreya Ghoshal]], Dhanunjay | length2 = 4:27 | title3 = Vasthane Vasthane | lyrics3 = [[Ramajogayya Sastry]] | extra3 = [[Hariharan (singer)|Hariharan]], [[Kousalya (singer)|Kousalya]] | length3 = 4:41 | title4 = Untale Untale | lyrics4 = Ramajogayya Sastry | extra4 = [[Malavika (singer)|Malavika]] | length4 = 2:14 | title5 = Addhira Banna | lyrics5 = Krishna Kanth | extra5 = [[Anudeep Dev]], Arun, Dhanunjay, Raghuram, Sampath, Prakash, Lokesh | length5 = 2:03 | title6 = Soggade Chinni Nayana | lyrics6 = [[Anantha Sreeram]] | extra6 = Satya Yamini, Nuthana, Vinayak | length6 = 4:05 }} === Reception === According to Karthik Srinivasan of ''[[The Hindu]]'', the [[Hook (music)|hook]] of "Dikka Dikka Dum Dum" resembles one written by [[A. R. Rahman]] for the Tamil song "Kaatre En Vasal" from ''[[Rhythm (2000 film)|Rhythm]]'' (2000): ''"Thulli varum kaatre, thulli varun kaatre, thaaimozhi pesu"''. Srinivasan called its melody "heady, raucous and very rhythmic".{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/hitman-songs-you-must-listen-to-this-week/article8146169.ece |title=Hitman: Songs you must listen to this week |work=The Hindu |date=24 January 2016 |accessdate=24 September 2016 |last=Srinivasan |first=Karthik |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924095035/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/hitman-songs-you-must-listen-to-this-week/article8146169.ece |archivedate=24 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Sangeetha Devi Dundoo from ''The Hindu'' wrote that Rubens' music complemented the film's rural backdrop. [[Sify]] called Rubens' music one of the film's biggest strengths, which "perfectly gelled with the rustic storyline". == Notes == {{Notelist}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|5340522}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:2010s supernatural films]] [[Category:Telugu-language films]] [[Category:Indian drama films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Telugu films remade in other languages]] [[Category:Films shot in Andhra Pradesh]] [[Category:Films scored by Anoop Rubens]] [[Category:Films shot in Mysore]] [[Category:Films using computer-generated imagery]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Indian fantasy films]] [[Category:Films set in Andhra Pradesh]] [[Category:Telugu-language films dubbed in Tamil]]

{{references|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = SpurguX | image = | developer = Petri Niska | publisher = self-published | designer = | engine = proprietary | released = 1987 | genre = [[roguelike]] | modes = [[Single player]] | platforms = [[MS-DOS]], [[Unix]] }} '''''SpurguX''''' is a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[humour|humorous]] [[roguelike]] [[video game]] developed by Petri Niska in 1987. It was originally developed for [[MS-DOS]] and has later been ported to [[Unix]]. According to the manual, ''SpurguX'' is an "adventure game based on real life, where the [[anti-hero]] progresses through city districts looking for a bottle of [[brandy]], which is rumoured to be located on stage 50, accompanied only by a great thirst". The player advances among the roguelike tradition from one stage to the next accumulating equipment, killing "monsters" and trying to survive. One of the most common causes of death is [[hangover]], which occurs when the player's blood alcohol level drops too low. Because of this, the player must constantly maintain the character's [[alcohol intoxication]] level by acquiring and drinking [[alcoholic beverage]]s. Most stages have points that have to be collected before advancing to the next stage, as well as a random collection of non-player characters, items and buildings. ==Characters== * @: The player. * C: A [[policeman]]. The police start to chase the player if he/she does something illegal. * M: A grandmother. Grandmothers can be killed fairly easily, but this causes the police to attack the player. Killing a grandmother yields money, which can be used for example to buy alcohol. * B: A point fairy. Bounces randomly around the stage eating the points needed for completion of the stage. Hitting the point fairy causes a point to be recreated in a random place. * N: A [[negro]]. * T: A [[Aalto University|University of Technology]] student. Forcibly sells a copy of ''[[Äpy]]'' magazine to the player. * P: A [[punk subculture|punk]]. Punks appear in gangs, and killing the gang leader (Ñ) awards a set of chains. The chains are among the most powerful weapons in the game. * K: Kake. Asks the player to give him [[beer]]. * V: A [[pickpocket]]. * H: A [[homosexuality|gay]] man. * h: A [[prostitute]], who offers herself for the price of 50 [[Finnish markka|markka]]. * O: A [[skinhead]]. * Q: A liquor smuggler. * I: A [[hippie]]. Hits the player with a drug-infused needle, which causes the player to reappear at a random stage and [[hallucination|hallucinate]]. While hallucinating, the player character cannot attack gay men, but instead sees them as "nice boys". * A: Sven-Olof, an [[AIDS]] carrier. Infects the player character with AIDS. * J: A [[yuppie]]. * Ω: A [[bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]]. Sometimes appears at the gate leading to the next stage, asking for a tip, which usually amounts to whatever amount the player is currently carrying. * R: A [[priest]]. Preaches about the dangers of alcohol. * E: A prison escapee. * G: A [[gorilla]]. * U: A country yokel. * D: A dog. * L: A social security worker. * S: A snake. * X: A politician. * Y: A [[Roma people|gypsy]]. * : A [[ghost]]. Cannot be seen. * Z: An [[army recruit]]. ==Buildings== * [[Alko]] sells liquor, if the player happens to have money. * The [[antiquarian]] can buy used things from the player. * The police station sends new policemen after the player, if he/she happens to be in trouble with the police. The player can also pay his/her fines at the police station should there be a search warrant for him/her. * The [[Helsinki metro|metro station]] is infested with skinheads. * The [[graveyard]] has a priest walking along it, preaching about the dangers of alcohol. * The [[pharmacy]] sells a drug that cures AIDS. ==Items== * [[Overalls]] * [[Camel (cigarette)|Camel]] boots * A [[Club (weapon)|nightstick]] * A [[stiletto knife]] * Chains * ''Äpy'' magazine * A [[sausage]] * An [[apple]] * A bar of [[chocolate]] * A can of [[long drink]] * A can of beer * A bottle of brandy ==See also== * ''[[Nethack]]'' ==External links== * [http://www.jonneweb.net/pelit/file/603/spurgux/ A freely downloadable version of the game] * [http://www.pelikapseli.net/old/skool/pelit/2006--2/spurgux/spurgux.html Review in ''Pelikapseli'' online magazine] [[Category:1987 video games]] [[Category:Roguelike video games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:Unix games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Finland]]

{{short description|Wrestling style}} {{Infobox martial art | image = Danwon-Ssireum.jpg | imagecaption = The painting titled "'''Sangbak'''" (상박; 相撲) drawn by [[Kim Hong-do]] illustrates people gathering around to watch a ssireum competition in the late 18th century. | imagesize = | name = ''Ssireum'' | aka = ''gakjeo''; ''gakhui''; ''gakryeok''; ''gakgii''; ''chiuhui''; ''sangbak''; ''jaenggyo'' | focus = [[Grappling]] | hardness = [[Full-contact]] | country = {{flagicon|Korea}} [[Korea]] | creator = Unknown | parenthood = Historical | famous_pract = | olympic = No | website = }}
{{Infobox Korean name | hangul = {{linktext|씨름}} | rr = ssireum | mr = ssirŭm }}
'''''Ssireum''''' ([[Hangul]]: 씨름) or '''Korean wrestling''' is a [[folk wrestling]] style and traditional [[national sport]] of [[Korea]] since the fourth century.
In the modern form each contestant wears a belt (satba) that wraps around the waist and the thigh. The competition employs a series of techniques, which inflict little harm or injury to the opponent: opponents lock on to each other's belt, and one achieves victory by bringing any part of the opponent's body above the knee to the ground.<ref>[http://ynucc.yeungnam.ac.kr/~ssi/Introduction/What_is_Ssireum_/what_is_ssireum_.html What is Ssireum?] ''Korean Ssireum Research Institute''.</ref>
== Etymology == Historically, with the introduction of Chinese culture, there have been other terms for "wrestling" in Korean used alongside ''ssireum'', such as ''gakjeo'' (각저:角抵), ''gakhui'' (각희:角戱), ''gakryeok'' (각력:角力), ''gakji'' (각지:角支), ''chiuhui'' (치우희:蚩尤戱), ''sangbak'' (상박:相撲), ''jaenggyo'' (쟁교:爭交).<ref>{{ko icon}} [http://www.yonginss.com/data/data_view.php?idx=7&page=1&search_txt=&search_sel= Origin and definition of ssireum 씨름의 정의] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319015817/http://www.yonginss.com/data/data_view.php?idx=7&page=1&search_txt=&search_sel= |date=2009-03-19 }} Yongin University Ssireum Research Center</ref> ''Gak'' (각:角), a commonly used prefix, seems to have originated from the combative act performed by horned animals such as oxen when competing against one another for the superiority of physical strength.
== History == The earliest evidence of ''ssireum'', or "Korean wrestling", dates back to the Goguryeo period. Originally used in military applications, ''ssireum'' became a popular pastime of the people, including many Korean kings, during the Goryeo and Joseon periods.<ref name="Green">{{cite book|last1=Green|first1=Thomas A.|last2=Svinth|first2=Joseph R.|title=Martial Arts of the World: An Encyclopedia of History and Innovation [2 volumes]: An Encyclopedia of History and Innovation|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781598842449|pages=192–193|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P-Nv_LUi6KgC&pg=PA192#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en|date=2010-06-11}}</ref>[[File:Goguryeo-Gakjeochong-Ssireumdo-01.jpg|thumb|200px|Ssireum depicted on Goguryeo mural]]
In traditional life, Ssireum was a popular activity on the Korean holiday of [[Dano (Korean festival)|Dano]], the fifth day of the fifth lunar month, and tournaments are held in the summer and autumn. Ssireum competitions were also held on other days such as the Third Day of the Third Moon, the Eighth day of the Fourth Moon, Buddhist All Souls’ Day, etc.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}. The traditional prize for winning a tournament was an ox, a valuable commodity in agriculturally-oriented society, which symbolized the strength of the contestant{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}.
In the 20th century, ''ssireum'' became a nationally televised sport in South Korea.<ref name="Green" /> The first modern competition was held in 1912 at the Dansongsa theater in Seoul{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}. Korean wrestling has been referred to as ''ssireum'' since the 1920s{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}. The Pan Chosun Ssireum Federation was founded in 1927. Since 1947 the competition organised by the Ssireum Federation has been called the National Ssireum Championship Contest. Weight classes were introduced at the 12th National Ssireum Championship Contest, and revised in 1967{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}. There are two traditional styles of Ssireum: a "right sided" style predominant in parts of the Gyunggi province, and Honam province of southern Korea, and a "left side" style favoured in Hamgyung province, Gyungsang province and Choonchong province. The difference depended on the way the ''satba'' was fastened{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}. In 1994, the Korean Ssireum federation, chaired by Hong sup Kim, proposed the unification of Ssireum in a single style and left sided Ssireum was adopted as the official style to be used by all competitors.
=== World cultural heritage status === On November 26, 2018, the Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of [[Unesco]] inscribed traditional Korean wrestling, (ssirum/ssireum) following an unprecedented joint application by the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea and the Republic of Korea.<ref>https://en.unesco.org/news/traditional-korean-wrestling-listed-intangible-cultural-heritage-following-unprecedented-merged</ref>
== Method of competition == [[File:Korea-2008 Gyeongju Citizens' Athletics Festival-Ssireum-02.jpg|thumb|A ssrireum match at Gyeongju Citizens' Athletics Festival in 2008]] [[File:Korea-2008 Gyeongju Citizens' Athletics Festival-Ssireum-01.jpg|thumb|A ssrireum match at Gyeongju Citizens' Athletics Festival in 2008]] Ssireum is conducted within a circular ring, measuring approximately 7 meters in diameter, which is covered with mounded sand. The two contestants begin the match by kneeling on the sand in a grappling position (''baro japki''), each grabbing a belt—known as a ''satba'' (샅바)<ref>{{cite book|last=Connor|first=Mary E.|title=The Koreas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j2gYgXGENM0C&pg=PA325|accessdate=16 January 2012|date=2009-06-30|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-160-2|page=325}}</ref>—which is wrapped around his opponent's waist and thigh. The wrestlers then rise while retaining their hold on the other's 'satba.' The match is awarded to the wrestler who forces the other contestant to touch the ground with any part of his body at knee level or higher. Unlike [[sumo]], pushing your opponent outside of the ring does not warrant a win, just a restart. Normally, professional ssireum is contested in a best-out-of-three style match.
There are 3 judges, a chief referee and three sub referees. The chief judge is positioned inside the ring, whereas the sub referees are located on the outside of the ring, one to the right and others to the left. If an unfair judgment is called or the chief referee is unable to render a decision, the sub referees can request a revocation of the decision or a rematch. In addition, they can recommend the cessation of the match when an injury occurs. The referees’ decisions throughout the competition are absolute and held in the highest regard, meaning that athletes cannot challenge any judgments declared during the match.
Today there are also women Ssireum wrestlers. Women wrestle only among themselves but follow the same rules (except that men are topless whereas women wear tops).
There are 4 weight classes in professional wrestling: flyweight ([[Taebaeksan|Taebaek]], 75 kg), lightweight ([[Kumgangsan|Geumgang]], 90 kg), middleweight ([[Hallasan|Halla]], 105 kg), and heavyweight ([[Baekdusan|Baekdu]], under 160 kg), named after the four famous peaks in Korea.<ref>{{cite web |title=Korean Wrestle Mania |url=https://tripologist.com/asia/korean-wrestle-mania-the-2012-seollal-ssireum-tournament/ |website=Tripologist |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
Traditionally Ssireum was contested with the top portion of the trousers rolled down to provide grip. The use of "satba" was invented with the birth of professional Ssireum in the mid-20th century. There is a movement to restore this traditional method of grip, in the spirit of maintaining its cultural and traditional roots, but it has met with some resistance as the use of "satba" has become entrenched in the modern form.
The professional league is dwindling in popularity and many wrestlers have turned their attention to [[mixed martial arts]] fighting, even though Ssireum involves no striking or submissions of any kind, as a means of making a living. [[Choi Hong-man]], former champion of Ssireum, is enjoying notable success in the [[K-1]] scene. Unfortunately, the future of professional Ssireum remains bleak, with only one team remaining. However, it can also be argued that Ssireum is beginning to undergo global expansion as a popular martial arts sport, alongside [[taekwondo]] and [[hapkido]].
It is important to note the differences between Ssireum and sumo. Ssireum has remained largely a national/traditional sport. Physical hits such as slaps and blows are not permitted in Ssireum, though they are in sumo. In both sports, the competitors are often quite large, though Korean wrestlers tend to be leaner. However, size does not guarantee success in either sport. Although both sports are quite similar, they differ in characteristics as well as values.
The national governing body of the sport in Korea, Korean Ssireum Organization, has made a claim that Ssireum is characterized as a "peaceful competition focusing on harmony and unison", reflecting the "philosophical outlook of the Korean Race".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ssirum.or.kr/korea/kor_ssireum01_eng.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-10-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080131084423/http://www.ssirum.or.kr/korea/kor_ssireum01_eng.php |archivedate=2008-01-31 |df= }}</ref>
== Events == === World Ssireum Championships === {{main|World Ssireum Championships}} 1st Asia Ssireum Championship and 5th World Ssireum Championship, which took place simultaneously at Thuwana National Indoor Stadium in Yangon, Myanmar, from September 18 to 23 of 2015. <ref>http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/?p=16398</ref> The second World Ssireum Championships are set to take place in Siauliai, Lithuania Friday, where a total of 120 wrestlers and 80 representatives and officials from 40 countries will participate in the two-day event, according to the World Ssireum Federation (WSF). The first championships were held in September 2008 during the Busan World TreX-Games. <ref>http://m.koreatimes.co.kr/phone/news/view.jsp?req_newsidx=51411</ref> (2008 is unofficial) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center |- !width=30|Edition !width=30|Year !width=100|Host City !width=175|Country !width=30|Events |- |1||'''[[2009 World Ssireum Championships|2009]]''' || [[Siauliai]] || align="left"|{{LTU}} || |- |2||'''[[2011 World Ssireum Championships|2011]]''' || [[Seoul]] || align="left"|{{KOR}} || |- |3||'''[[2012 World Ssireum Championships|2012]]''' || [[Busan]] || align="left"|{{KOR}} || |- |4||'''[[2013 World Ssireum Championships|2013]]''' || [[Frankfurt]] || align="left"|{{GER}} || |- |5||'''[[2015 World Ssireum Championships|2015]]''' || [[Yangon]] || align="left"|{{MYA}} || |- |6||'''[[2017 World Ssireum Championships|2017]]''' || || || |} * http://www.worldssireum.org/ - '''World Ssireum Federation (WSF)''' * http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/?p=16398 * http://worldssireum.org/en_01_about/en_about03.php?ptype=en01_03 * http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/Sports/view?articleId=90191 * http://www.sumoforum.net/forums/topic/18609-ssireum-world-championships-in-lithuania/ * https://www.thetvdb.com/?tab=episode&seriesid=270403&seasonid=521699&id=4583700&lid=7 (World Water Ssireum Championship) * http://m.koreatimes.co.kr/phone/news/view.jsp?req_newsidx=51411
=== Asian Ssireum Championships === {{main|Asian Ssireum Championships}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center |- !width=30|Edition !width=30|Year !width=100|Host City !width=175|Country !width=30|Events |- |1||'''[[2015 Asian Kurash Championships|2015]]''' || [[Yangon]] || align="left"|{{MYA}} || |- |2||'''[[2017 Asian Kurash Championships|2017]]''' || || |}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{About|stage theater in the United States|information about the movie industry|Cinema of the United States}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{UStheater}} '''Theater in the United States''' is part of the European theatrical tradition that dates back to [[Theatre of ancient Greece|ancient Greek theatre]] and is heavily influenced by the [[Theatre of the United Kingdom|British theatre]]. The central hub of the US theater scene is [[New York City]], with its divisions of [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], [[Off-Broadway]], and [[Off-Off-Broadway]]. Many movie and television stars got their big break working in New York productions. Outside New York, many cities have professional [[Regional theater in the United States|regional or resident theater companies]] that produce their own seasons, with some works being produced regionally with hopes of eventually moving to New York. US theater also has an active [[community theatre]] culture, which relies mainly on local volunteers who may not be actively pursuing a theatrical career.
==Early history== {{US culture}} [[File:Edwin Forrest.jpg|thumb|left|[[Edwin Forrest]], a popular early American actor]] Before the first English colony was established in 1607, there were Spanish dramas and Native American tribes that performed theatrical events.<ref name= "World Encyclopedia">{{cite book |title=The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: The Americas |last= |first= |authorlink= |authors= |editor1-first=Don |editor1-last=Rubin |editor1-link= |editor2-first=Carlos |editor2-last=Solórzano |editor2-link=Carlos Solórzano |year=2000 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York City |isbn=0-415-05929-1 |page=394 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
Although a theater was built in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]] in 1716, and the original [[Dock Street Theatre]] opened in [[Charleston, South Carolina]] in 1736, the birth of professional theater in America may have begun when [[Lewis Hallam]] arrived with his theatrical company in Williamsburg in 1752.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Arthur Hornblow|title=The Coming of the Hallams|url=http://www.theatrehistory.com/american/hornblow03.html|website=Theatrehistory.com|publisher=J.B. Lippincott Company|accessdate=December 15, 2016|location=Philadelphia|pages=66–87|date=1919|quote=A History of the Theatre in America, Vol. 1}}</ref> Lewis and his brother [[William Hallam (theatre manager)|William]], who arrived in 1754, were the first to organize a complete company of actors in Europe and bring them to the [[Thirteen Colonies|colonies]]. They brought a repertoire of plays popular in London at the time, including ''[[Hamlet]]'', ''[[Othello]]'', ''[[The Recruiting Officer]]'', and ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]''. ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]'' was their first performance, shown initially on September 15, 1752.<ref name="theatrehistory.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.theatrehistory.com/american/hornblow01.html|title=The First American Theatre|website=Theatrehistory.com|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref> Encountering opposition from religious organizations, Hallam and his company left for [[Jamaica]] in 1754 or 1755.{{Citation needed|reason=date: September 14, 2008|date=September 2008}} Soon after, [[Lewis Hallam, Jr.]], founded the American Company, opened a theater in New York, and presented the first professionally mounted American play—''[[The Prince of Parthia]]'', by [[Thomas Godfrey (writer)|Thomas Godfrey]]—in 1767.<ref>''The Prince of Parthia: A Tragedy'' By Thomas Godfrey, reprinted 1917 by Little, Brown.</ref>
In the 18th century, laws forbidding the performance of plays were passed in [[Massachusetts]] in 1750, in [[Pennsylvania]] in 1759, and in [[Rhode Island]] in 1761, and plays were banned in most states during the [[American Revolutionary War]] at the urging of the [[Continental Congress]].<ref name="theatrehistory.com"/> In 1794, president of [[Yale College]], [[Timothy Dwight IV]], in his "Essay on the Stage", declared that "to indulge a taste for playgoing means nothing more or less than the loss of that most valuable treasure: the immortal soul."{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
In spite of such laws, however, a few writers tried their hand at playwriting. Most likely, the first plays written in America were by European-born authors—we know of original plays being written by Spaniards, Frenchmen and Englishmen dating back as early as 1567—although no plays were printed in America until [[Robert Hunter (governor)|Robert Hunter's]] ''[[Androboros]]'' in 1714. Still, in the early years, most of the plays produced came from Europe; only with Godfrey's ''The Prince of Parthia'' in 1767 do we get a professionally produced play written by an American, although it was a last-minute substitute for Thomas Forrest's comic opera ''[[The Disappointment|The Disappointment; or, The Force of Credulity]]'', and although the first play to treat American themes seriously, ''Ponteach; or, the Savages of America'' by [[Robert Rogers (soldier)|Robert Rogers]], had been published in London a year earlier.<ref name=Meserve>Meserve, Walter J. ''An Outline History of American Drama,'' New York: Feedback/Prospero, 1994.</ref> 'Cato', a play about revolution, was performed for George Washington and his troops at Valley Forge in the winter of 1777–1778.
The [[American Revolution|Revolutionary period]] was a boost for dramatists, for whom the political debates were fertile ground for both satire, as seen in the works of [[Mercy Otis Warren]] and Colonel Robert Munford, and for plays about heroism, as in the works of [[Hugh Henry Brackenridge]]. The post-war period saw the birth of American social comedy in [[Royall Tyler]]'s ''[[The Contrast (play)|The Contrast]]'', which established a much-imitated version of the "Yankee" character, here named "Jonathan". But there were no professional dramatists until [[William Dunlap]], whose work as playwright, translator, manager and theater historian has earned him the title of "Father of American Drama"; in addition to translating the plays of [[August von Kotzebue]] and French melodramas, Dunlap wrote plays in a variety of styles, of which ''[[André (play)|André]]'' and ''[[The Father (Dunlap play)|The Father; or, American Shandyism]]'' are his best.<ref name=Meserve/>
==The 19th century== ===Pre-war theater=== At 825 Walnut Street in [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania, is the [[Walnut Street Theatre]], or, "The Walnut." Founded in 1809 by the [[Circus of Pepin and Breschard]], "The Walnut" is the oldest theater in America. The Walnut's first theatrical production, ''The Rivals'', was staged in 1812. In attendance were President [[Thomas Jefferson]] and the [[Marquis de Lafayette]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walnutstreettheatre.org|title=Walnut Street Theatre – Philadelphia, PA – Official Website|website=Walnutstreettheatre.org|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref>
Provincial theaters frequently lacked heat and minimal [[theatrical property]] ("props") and [[theatrical scenery|scenery]]. Apace with the country's [[westward expansion]], some entrepreneurs operated floating theaters on [[barge]]s or [[riverboat]]s that would travel from town to town. A large town could afford a long "run"—or period of time during which a touring company would stage consecutive multiple performances—of a production, and in 1841, a single play was shown in New York City for an unprecedented three weeks.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
[[File:John Drew as Petruchio.jpg|thumb|left|[[John Drew, Jr.|John Drew]], a famous American actor, playing the part of Petruchio from ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]''.]]
[[William Shakespeare]]'s works were commonly performed. American plays of the period were mostly [[melodrama]]s, a famous example of which was ''[[Uncle Tom's Cabin]]'', adapted by [[George Aiken]], from the novel of the same name by [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]].
In 1821, William Henry Brown established the [[African Grove|African Grove Theatre]] in New York City. It was the third attempt to have an African-American theater, but this was the most successful of them all. The company put on not only Shakespeare, but also staged the first play written by an African-American, ''[[The Drama of King Shotaway]]''. The theater was shut down in 1823.<ref name="World Encyclopedia, p. 402">World Encyclopedia, p. 402</ref> African-American theater was relatively dormant, except for the 1858 play ''The Escape; or, A Leap for Freedom'' by [[William Wells Brown]], who was an ex-slave. African-American works would not be regarded again until the 1920s [[Harlem Renaissance]].<ref name="World Encyclopedia, p. 402"/>
A popular form of theater during this time was the [[minstrel show]], which featured white (and sometimes, especially after the Civil War, [[black people|black]]) actors dressed in "[[blackface]] (painting one's face, etc. with dark makeup to imitate the coloring of an [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]] or African American)." The players entertained the audience using comic skits, parodies of popular plays and musicals, and general buffoonery and slapstick comedy, all with heavy utilization of [[racial stereotype|racial stereotyping]] and [[racism|racist]] themes.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
Throughout the 19th century, theater culture was associated with [[hedonism]] and even violence, and actors (especially women), were looked upon as little better than prostitutes. [[Jessie Bond]] wrote that by the middle of the 19th century, "The stage was at a low ebb, Elizabethan glories and Georgian artificialities had alike faded into the past, stilted tragedy and vulgar farce were all the would-be playgoer had to choose from, and the theatre had become a place of evil repute".<ref name=Bond>{{cite web|url=http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/books/bond/intro.html|title=The Life and Reminiscences of Jessie Bond – Introduction|website=math.boisestate.edu|accessdate=October 4, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421204843/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/books/bond/intro.html|archivedate=April 21, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On April 15, 1865, less than a week after the end of the [[United States Civil War]], [[Abraham Lincoln]], while watching [[Our American Cousin|a play]] at [[Ford's Theater]] in Washington, D.C., [[Abraham Lincoln#Assassination|was assassinated]] by a nationally popular stage-actor of the period, [[John Wilkes Booth]].
[[Victorian burlesque]], a form of bawdy comic theater mocking high art and culture, was imported from England about 1860 and in America became a form of [[farce]] in which females in male roles mocked the politics and culture of the day. Criticized for its sexuality and outspokenness, this form of entertainment was hounded off the "legitimate stage" and found itself relegated to saloons and [[Bar (establishment)|barrooms]].{{Citation needed|reason=date: September 14, 2008|date=September 2008}} The female producers, such as [[Lydia Thompson]] were replaced by their male counterparts, who toned down the politics and played up the sexuality, until the [[American burlesque|burlesque shows]] eventually became little more than pretty girls in skimpy clothing singing songs, while male comedians told raunchy jokes.
The drama of the pre-war period tended to be a derivative in form, imitating European melodramas and romantic tragedies, but native in content, appealing to popular nationalism by dramatizing current events and portraying American heroism. But playwrights were limited by a set of factors, including the need for plays to be profitable, the middle-brow tastes of American theater-goers, and the lack of copyright protection and compensation for playwrights. During this time, the best strategy for a dramatist was to become an actor and/or a manager, after the model of [[John Howard Payne]], [[Dion Boucicault]] and [[John Brougham]]. This period saw the popularity of certain native character types, especially the "Yankee", the "Negro" and the "Indian", exemplified by the characters of [[Brother Jonathan|Jonathan]], [[Sambo (racial term)|Sambo]] and [[Metamora; or, The Last of the Wampanoags|Metamora]]. Meanwhile, increased immigration brought a number of plays about the Irish and Germans, which often dovetailed with concerns over temperance and Roman Catholic. This period also saw plays about American expansion to the West (including plays about Mormonism) and about women's rights. Among the best plays of the period are [[James Nelson Barker]]'s ''Superstition; or, the Fanatic Father'', [[Anna Cora Mowatt]]'s ''Fashion; or, Life in New York'', [[Nathaniel Bannister]]'s ''[[Putnam, the Iron Son of '76]]'', [[Dion Boucicault]]'s ''[[The Octoroon|The Octoroon; or, Life in Louisiana]]'', and [[Cornelius Mathews]]'s ''Witchcraft; or, the Martyrs of Salem''. At the same time, America had created new dramatic forms in the [[Tom Shows]], the [[showboat|showboat theater]] and the [[minstrel show]].<ref name=Meserve/>
===Post-war theater=== In the [[Reconstruction era of the United States|postbellum]] North, theater flourished as a post-war boom allowed longer and more-frequent productions. The advent of American rail transport allowed production companies, its actors, and large, elaborate sets to travel easily between towns, which made permanent theaters in small towns feasible. The invention and practical application of [[electric light]]ing also led to changes to and improvements of scenery styles and the designing of theater interiors and seating areas.
[[File:Howard and Griffin wench.jpg|right|thumb|175px|Minstrel show performers Rollin Howard (in female costume) and George Griffin, c. 1855.]]
In 1896, [[Charles Frohman]], [[Al Hayman]], [[Abe Erlanger]], [[Marcus Klaw|Mark Klaw]], Samuel F. Flenderson, and [[J. Fred Zimmerman, Sr.]] formed the [[Theatrical Syndicate]], which established systemized [[Talent agent|booking]] networks throughout the United States, and created a management monopoly that controlled every aspect of contracts and bookings until the turn of the 20th century, when the [[Shubert brothers]] founded rival agency, [[The Shubert Organization]].
For playwrights, the period after the War brought more financial reward and aesthetic respect (including professional criticism) than was available earlier. In terms of form, spectacles, melodramas and farces remained popular, but poetic drama and romanticism almost died out completely due to the new emphasis upon realism, which was adopted by serious drama, melodrama and comedy alike. This realism was not quite the European realism of [[Henrik Ibsen|Ibsen]]'s ''[[Ghosts (play)|Ghosts]]'', but a combination of scenic realism (e.g., the "[[David Belasco|Belasco]] Method") with a less romantic view of life that accompanied the cultural turmoil of the period. The most ambitious effort towards realism during this period came from [[James Herne]], who was influenced by the ideas of Ibsen, [[Thomas Hardy|Hardy]] and [[Émile Zola|Zola]] regarding realism, truth, and literary quality; his most important achievement, ''[[Margaret Fleming]]'', enacts the principles he expounded in his essay "Art for Truth's Sake in the Drama". Although ''Fleming'' did not appeal to audiences—critics and audiences felt it dwelt too much on unseemly topics and included improper scenes, such as Margaret nursing her husband's bastard child onstage—other forms of dramatic realism were becoming more popular in melodrama (e.g., [[Augustin Daly]]'s ''[[Under the Gaslight]]'') and in [[American literary regionalism|local color]] plays ([[Bronson Howard]]'s ''Shenandoah''). Other key dramatists during this period are [[David Belasco]], [[Steele MacKaye]], [[William Dean Howells]], [[Dion Boucicault]], and [[Clyde Fitch]].<ref name=Meserve/>
==The 20th century== [[Vaudeville]] was common in the late 19th and early 20th century, and is notable for heavily influencing early film, radio, and television productions in the country. (This was born from an earlier American practice of having singers and novelty acts perform between acts in a standard play.) [[George Burns]] was a very long-lived American comedian who started out in the vaudeville community, but went on to enjoy a career running until the 1990s.
Some vaudeville theaters built between about 1900 and 1920 managed to survive as well, though many went through periods of alternate use, most often as movie theaters until the second half of the century saw many urban populations decline and [[movie theater|multiplexes]] built in the suburbs. Since that time, a number have been restored to original or nearly-original condition and attract new audiences nearly one hundred years later.
By the beginning of the 20th century, legitimate 1752 (non-vaudeville) theater had become decidedly more sophisticated in the United States, as it had in Europe. The stars of this era, such as [[Ethel Barrymore]] and [[John Barrymore]], were often seen as even more important than the show itself. The advance of motion pictures also led to many changes in theater. The popularity of musicals may have been due in part to the fact the [[Silent film|early films]] had no sound, and could thus not compete, until ''[[The Jazz Singer]]'' of 1927, which combined both talking and music in a moving picture. More complex and sophisticated dramas bloomed in this time period, and acting styles became more subdued. Even by 1915, actors were being lured away from theater and to the [[silver screen]], and vaudeville was beginning to face stiff competition.
While [[revue]]s consisting of mostly unconnected songs, sketches, comedy routines, and dancing girls ([[Ziegfeld girl]]s) dominated for the first 20 years of the 20th century, musical theater would eventually develop beyond this. One of the first major steps was ''[[Show Boat]]'', with music by [[Jerome Kern]] and lyrics by [[Oscar Hammerstein II|Oscar Hammerstein]]. It featured songs and non-musical scenes which were integrated to develop the show's plot. The next great step forward was ''[[Oklahoma!]]'', with lyrics by Hammerstein and music by [[Richard Rodgers]]. Its "dream ballets" used dance to carry forward the plot and develop the characters.
Amateur performing groups have always had a place alongside professional acting companies. The Amateur Comedy Club, Inc. was founded in New York City on April 18, 1884. It was organized by seven gentlemen who broke away from the Madison Square Dramatic Organization, a socially prominent company presided over by Mrs. James Brown Potter and [[David Belasco]]. The ACC staged its first performance on February 13, 1885. It has performed continuously ever since, making it the oldest, continuously performing theatrical society in the United States. Prominent New Yorkers who have been members of the ACC include Theodore, Frederick and John Steinway of the piano manufacturing family; Gordon Grant, the marine artist; Christopher La Farge, the architect; Van H. Cartmell, the publisher; [[Albert Sterner]], the painter; and Edward Fales Coward, the theater critic and playwright. [[Elsie De Wolfe]], Lady Mendl, later famous as the world's first professional interior decorator, acted in Club productions in the early years of the 20th Century, as did [[Hope Williams]], and Julie Harris in the 1940s.
Early 20th century theater was dominated by the [[Barrymore acting family|Barrymores]]—[[Ethel Barrymore]], [[John Barrymore]], and [[Lionel Barrymore]]. Other greats included [[Laurette Taylor]], [[Jeanne Eagels]], and [[Eva Le Gallienne]]. The massive social change that went on during the [[Great Depression]] also had an effect on theater in the United States. Plays took on social roles, identifying with immigrants and the unemployed. The [[Federal Theatre Project]], a [[New Deal]] program set up by [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], helped to promote theater and provide jobs for actors. The program staged many elaborate and controversial plays such as ''[[It Can't Happen Here]]'' by [[Sinclair Lewis]] and ''[[The Cradle Will Rock]]'' by [[Marc Blitzstein]]. By contrast, the legendary producer [[Brock Pemberton]] (founder of the [[Tony Awards]]) was among those who felt that it was more than ever a time for comic entertainment, in order to provide an escape from the prevailing harsh social conditions: typical of his productions was [[Lawrence Riley]]'s comedy ''[[Personal Appearance]]'' (1934), whose success on Broadway (501 performances) vindicated Pemberton.
The years between the World Wars were years of extremes. [[Eugene O'Neill]]'s plays were the high point for serious dramatic plays leading up to the outbreak of war in Europe. ''[[Beyond the Horizon (play)|Beyond the Horizon]]'' (1920), for which he won his first Pulitzer Prize; he later won Pulitzers for ''[[Anna Christie]]'' (1922) and ''[[Strange Interlude]]'' (1928) as well as the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]]. [[Alfred Lunt]] and [[Lynn Fontanne]] remained a popular acting couple in the 1930s.
1940 proved to be a pivotal year for African-American theater. [[Frederick O'Neal]] and Abram Hill founded ANT, or the [[American Negro Theater]], the most renowned African-American theater group of the 1940s. Their stage was small and located in the basement of a library in Harlem, and most of the shows were attended and written by African-Americans. Some shows include Theodore Browne's ''Natural Man'' (1941), Abram Hill's ''Walk Hard'' (1944), and [[Owen Dodson]]'s ''Garden of Time'' (1945). Many famous actors received their training at ANT, including [[Harry Belafonte]], [[Sidney Poitier]], [[Alice Childress|Alice]] and [[Alvin Childress]], Osceola Archer, [[Ruby Dee]], [[Earle Hyman]], [[Hilda Simms]], among many others.<ref>World Encyclopedia, p. 403</ref>
Mid-20th century theater saw a wealth of Great Leading Ladies, including [[Helen Hayes]], [[Katherine Cornell]], [[Tallulah Bankhead]], [[Judith Anderson]], and [[Ruth Gordon]]. Musical theater saw stars such as [[Ethel Merman]], [[Beatrice Lillie]], [[Mary Martin]], and [[Gertrude Lawrence]].
===Post World War II theater=== After World War II, American theater came into its own. Several American playwrights, such as [[Arthur Miller]] and [[Tennessee Williams]], became world-renowned.
In the 1950s and 1960s, experimentation in the Arts spread into theater as well, with plays such as ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'' including [[nudity]] and drug culture references. Musicals remained popular as well, and musicals such as ''[[West Side Story (musical)|West Side Story]]'' and ''[[A Chorus Line]]'' broke previous records. At the same time, shows like [[Stephen Sondheim]]'s ''[[Company (musical)|Company]]'' began to deconstruct the musical form as it has been practiced through the mid-century, moving away from traditional plot and realistic external settings to explore the central character's inner state; his ''[[Follies]]'' relied on pastiches of the [[Ziegfeld Follies]]-styled revue; his ''[[Pacific Overtures]]'' used Japanese [[kabuki]] theatrical practices; and ''[[Merrily We Roll Along (musical)|Merrily We Roll Along]]'' told its story backwards. Similarly, [[Bob Fosse]]'s production of [[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]] returned the musical to its vaudeville origins.
'''Facts and figures of the post-war theater'''<!-- below is the official information, taken from the U.S. Congress hearings, copyright-free -->
The post-war American theater audiences and box offices constantly diminished, due to the undeclared "offensive" of television and radio upon the classical, [[legitimate theater]]. According to James F. Reilly, executive director of the [[League of New York Theatres]], between 1930 and 1951 the number of legitimate theaters in New York City dwindled from 68 to 30. Besides of that, the admissions tax, has been a burden on the theater since 1918. It was never relaxed ever since, and was doubled in 1943.<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=ien.35559007406253;view=1up;seq=848 Statement of James F. Reilly, executive director of the League of New York Theatres, New York, N.Y.]. Revenue Revision of 1951, hearings, 82nd Congress, p. 2362.</ref> Total seating capacity of thirty most renown legitimate theaters amounted 35,697 seats in 1951. Since 1937 in New York City alone, 14 former legitimate theaters with a normal seating capacity of 16,955, have been taken over for either [[radio broadcasts]] or [[Live television|television performances]].<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=ien.35559007406253;view=1up;seq=849 Seating capacity of present/former legitimate theaters]. Revenue Revision of 1951, hearings, 82nd Congress, p. 2363.</ref>
In the late 1990s and 2000s, American theater began to borrow from cinema and operas. For instance, [[Julie Taymor]], director of ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]'' directed ''[[Die Zauberflöte]]'' at the [[Metropolitan Opera]]. Also, Broadway musicals were developed around Disney's ''[[Mary Poppins (musical)|Mary Poppins]]'', ''[[Tarzan (musical)|Tarzan]]'', ''[[The Little Mermaid (musical)|The Little Mermaid]]'', and the one that started it all, ''[[Beauty and the Beast (musical)|Beauty and the Beast]]'', which may have contributed to [[Times Square]]'s revitalization in the 1990s. Also, [[Mel Brooks]]'s ''[[The Producers (musical)|The Producers]]'' and ''[[Young Frankenstein (musical)|Young Frankenstein]]'' are based on his hit films.
===Drama=== {{Expand section|coverage of the late 1990s and more information about the mid-century periods|date=July 2010}} The early years of the 20th century, before World War I, continued to see realism as the main development in drama. But starting around 1900, there was a revival of poetic drama in the States, corresponding to a similar revival in Europe (e.g. [[William Butler Yeats|Yeats]], [[Maurice Maeterlinck|Maeterlinck]] and [[Gerhart Hauptmann|Hauptmann]]). The most notable example of this trend was the "Biblical trilogy" of [[William Vaughn Moody]], which also illustrate the rise of religious-themed drama during the same years, as seen in the 1899 production of ''[[Ben-Hur (play)|Ben-Hur]]'' and two 1901 adaptations of ''[[Quo Vadis (novel)|Quo Vadis]]''. Moody, however, is best known for two prose plays, ''The Great Divide'' (1906, later [[The Great Divide (1925 film)|adapted into three film versions]]) and ''The Faith Healer'' (1909), which together point the way to modern American drama in their emphasis on the emotional conflicts that lie at the heart of contemporary social conflicts. Other key playwrights from this period (in addition to continued work by Howells and Fitch) include [[Edward Sheldon]], [[Charles Rann Kennedy (playwright)|Charles Rann Kennedy]] and one of the most successful women playwrights in American drama, [[Rachel Crothers]], whose interest in women's issues can be seen in such plays as ''He and She'' (1911).<ref name=Meserve/>
During the period between the World Wars, American drama came to maturity, thanks in large part to the works of [[Eugene O'Neill]] and of the [[Provincetown Players]]. O'Neill's experiments with theatrical form and his combination of [[Naturalism (theatre)|Naturalist]] and [[Expressionism (theatre)|Expressionist]] techniques inspired other playwrights to use greater freedom in their works, whether expanding the techniques of [[Realism (arts)|Realism]], as in [[Susan Glaspell]]'s ''[[Trifles]]'', or borrowing more heavily from German Expressionism (e.g., [[Elmer Rice]]'s ''[[The Adding Machine]]''), Other distinct movements during this period include folk-drama/regionalism ([[Paul Green (playwright)|Paul Green]]'s Pulitzer-winning ''[[In Abraham's Bosom]]''), "pageant" drama (Green's ''[[Lost Colony (play)|The Lost Colony]]'', about the mysterious [[Roanoke Colony]]), and even a return to poetic drama ([[Maxwell Anderson]]'s ''[[Winterset (play)|Winterset]]''). At the same time, the economic crisis of the [[Great Depression]] led to the growth of protest drama, as seen in the [[Federal Theatre Project]]'s [[Living Newspaper]] productions and in the works of [[Clifford Odets]] (e.g., ''[[Waiting for Lefty]]'') and of moralist drama, as in [[Lillian Hellman]]'s ''[[The Little Foxes]]'' and ''[[The Children's Hour (play)|The Children's Hour]]''. Other key figures of this era include [[George S. Kaufman]], [[George Kelly (playwright)|George Kelly]], [[Langston Hughes]], [[S. N. Behrman]], [[Sidney Howard]], [[Robert E. Sherwood]], and a set of playwrights who followed O'Neill's path of philosophical searching, [[Philip Barry]], [[Thornton Wilder]] (''[[Our Town]]'') and [[William Saroyan]] (''[[The Time of Your Life]]''). Theater criticism kept pace with the drama, such as in the work of [[George Jean Nathan]] and in the numerous books and journals on American theater that were published during this time.<ref name=Meserve/>
The stature that American drama had achieved between the Wars was cemented during the post-World War II generation, with the final works of O'Neill and his generation being joined by such towering figures as [[Tennessee Williams]] and [[Arthur Miller]], as well as by the maturation of the musical theatre form. Other key dramatists include [[William Inge]], [[Arthur Laurents]] and [[Paddy Chayefsky]] in the 1950s, the ''avant garde'' movement of [[Jack Richardson (playwright)|Jack Richardson]], [[Arthur Kopit]], [[Jack Gelber]] and [[Edward Albee]] the 1960s, and the maturation of black drama through [[Lorraine Hansberry]], [[James Baldwin (writer)|James Baldwin]] and [[Amiri Baraka]]. In the musical theater, important figures include [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]], [[Lerner and Loewe]], [[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]], [[Richard Adler]] and [[Jerry Ross (composer)|Jerry Ross]], [[Frank Loesser]], [[Jule Styne]], [[Jerry Bock]], [[Meredith Willson]] and [[Stephen Sondheim]].<ref name=Meserve/>
The period beginning in the mid-1960s, with the passing of Civil Rights legislation and its repercussions, came the rise of an "agenda" theater comparable to that of the 1930s. Many of the major playwrights from the mid-century continued to produce new works, but were joined by names like [[Sam Shepard]], [[Neil Simon]], [[Romulus Linney (playwright)|Romulus Linney]], [[David Rabe]], [[Lanford Wilson]], [[David Mamet]], and [[John Guare]]. Many important dramatists were women, including [[Beth Henley]], [[Marsha Norman]], [[Wendy Wasserstein]], [[Megan Terry]], [[Paula Vogel]] and [[María Irene Fornés]]. The growth of ethnic pride movements led to more success by dramatists from racial minorities, such as black playwrights [[Douglas Turner Ward]], [[Adrienne Kennedy]], [[Ed Bullins]], [[Charles Fuller]], [[Suzan-Lori Parks]], [[Ntozake Shange]], [[George C. Wolfe]] and [[August Wilson]], who created a dramatic history of United States with his cycle of plays, ''The Pittsburgh Cycle'', one for each decade of the 20th century. Asian-American theater is represented in the early 1970s by [[Frank Chin]] and achieved international success with [[David Henry Hwang]]'s ''[[M. Butterfly]]''. Latino theater grew from the local activist performances of [[Luis Valdez]]'s Chicano-focused ''[[Teatro Campesino]]'' to his more formal plays, such as ''[[Zoot Suit (play)|Zoot Suit]]'', and later to the award-winning work of Cuban Americans Fornés (multiple Obies) and her student [[Nilo Cruz]] (Pulitzer), to Puerto Rican playwrights [[José Rivera (playwright)|José Rivera]] and [[Miguel Piñero]], and to the Tony Award-winning musical about Dominicans in New York City, ''[[In the Heights]]''. Finally, the rise of the gay rights movement and of the AIDS crisis led to a number of important gay and lesbian dramatists, including [[Christopher Durang]], [[Holly Hughes (performance artist)|Holly Hughes]], [[Karen Malpede]], [[Terrence McNally]], [[Larry Kramer]], [[Tony Kushner]], whose ''[[Angels in America]]'' won the Tony Award two years in a row, and composer-playwright [[Jonathan Larson]], whose musical ''[[Rent (musical)|Rent]]'' ran for over twelve years.<ref name=Meserve/>
==American theater today== Earlier styles of theater such as [[minstrel show]]s and [[Vaudeville]] acts have disappeared from the landscape, but theater remains a popular American art form. Broadway productions still entertain millions of theater-goers as productions have become more elaborate and expensive. At the same time, theater has also served as a platform for expression, and a venue for identity exploration for under-represented, minority communities, who have formed their own companies and created their own genres of works, notably [[East West Players]], founded in 1965 as the first [[Asian-American theatre]] group. Notable contemporary American playwrights include [[Edward Albee]], [[August Wilson]], [[Tony Kushner]], [[David Henry Hwang]], [[John Guare]], and [[Wendy Wasserstein]]. Smaller urban theaters have stayed a source of innovation, and regional theaters remain an important part of theater life. Drama is also taught in high schools and colleges, which was not done in previous eras, and many become interested in theater through this.
''[[The Faster Times]]'', an online newspaper that ran from 2009 to 2013, featured a weekly column that discussed issues and trends in American theater.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thefastertimes.com/theatertalk/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090713175628/http://thefastertimes.com/theatertalk/ |archivedate=July 13, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} </ref>
[[HowlRound]], an online "commons", features opinions and essays by artists and academics in American Theater today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://howlround.com/about|title=About|website=Howlround.com|accessdate=October 4, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of playwrights from the United States]] *[[List of American plays]] *[[Dance in the United States]]

''American Drama between the Wars'' (1991) * Richardson, Gary A. ''American Drama through World War I'' (1997) * Roudane, Matthew Charles. ''American Drama Since 1960: A Critical History'' (1996) * Shiach, Don. ''American Drama 1900–1990'' (2000) * Watt, Stephen, and Gary A. Richardson. ''American Drama: Colonial to Contemporary'' (1994) * Weales, Gerald Clifford. ''American drama since World War II'' (1962)

{{Cleanup|date=January 2010}} '''Şerafettin Taşliova''' (1938 – 20 September 2014) was a Turkish storyteller in the [[Ashik|asik]] [[bardic]] tradition. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kultur.gov.tr/EN/Genel/BelgeGoster.aspx?17A16AE30572D313FFB2CB2AD591CE26BEC33B5F26CD2CF1 |title=Republic of Turkey Ministry of Culture and Tourism |publisher=Kultur.gov.tr Republic of Turkey, Ministry of Culture and Tourism |date= |accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crickcrackclub.com/CRICRACK/TELLWAF.HTM |title=Worldwide Storytellers |publisher=Crickcrackclub.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|author=Bekir Karadeniz |url=http://home.arcor.de/tasliova/ |title=Şeref Taşlıova |publisher=Home.arcor.de |date= |accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.turkuler.com/ozan/sereftasliova.asp |title=Şeref Taşlıova - Ozanlarımız |publisher=Turkuler.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref>
Taşliova has won many prizes at bardic contests for improvised poetry and storytelling; many at international level. He has also been awarded by UNESCO. He started writing poetry around the age of ten and is widely recognised for his ability to tell epic tales, being one of the most prominent figures in the northeastern Anatolian tradition of minstrelsy,
He is a prolific published author of poetry, and has also recorded many albums of his poetry and bardic stories.
Taşliova has also had a long career in broadcasting. He makes appearances on a number of Turkish television stations, and has been making a regular radio broadcast since 1966, he has also appeared in the [[Michael Wood (historian)|Michael Wood]] BBC documentaries ''[[In Search of the Trojan War]]'' (1985) and ''[[In the Footsteps of Alexander the Great]]'' (1997), in which he demonstrates the oral traditions of the storyteller.
==Early life== He was born in the village of [[Pekşeren]] ([[Gülyüzü]]), in the district of [[Çıldır]] in the [[Ardahan Province]], on April 10, 1938. His name translates as "honor". On September 13, 2014, he was carried to the Diskapi Yildirim Beyazit Training and Research Hospital. Seven days after he was operated, he died on September 20, 2014.<ref>Milliyet newspaper: [http://www.milliyet.com.tr/unesco-yasayan-insan-hazinesi--gundem-1943385/ "UNESCO 'yaşayan insan hazinesi' Aşık Şeref Taşlıova vefat etti."] September 21, 2014.</ref><ref>CNN Türk: [http://www.cnnturk.com/video/kultur-sanat/diger/devlet-sanatcisi-asik-seref-tasliova-vefat-etti "Devlet sanatçısı Aşık Şeref Taşlıova vefat etti."] September 21, 2014.</ref>
==Wider recognition== In 1986, the Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism established a database of living folk poets, 557 âşıks were registered in the database including Şeref Taşlıova. On the 4 July 2008 and using this database, Taşlıova was identified and nominated for UNESCO living human treasure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/doc/src/00179-Nomination_form.doc |title=Nomination for inscription on the Representative List in 2009 (Reference No. 00179). A. State party: Turkey. B. Name of element: Âşıklık (minstrelsy) tradition | publisher=Unesco. Convention for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage , Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage , Fourth session, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, 28 September to 2 October 2009 |date= |accessdate=2009-12-31}}</ref> These were the words of Şeref Taşlıova: {{cquote|I have received many awards, but this is by far the most valuable for me. I carried the others on my chest; this one I shall carry around on my head.<ref>Sunday's Zaman newspaper: [http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-199353-132-turkeys-living-treasures.html "Turkey’s living treasures."] January 23, 2010.</ref>}}
==Albums== *Wonderful, 1967 *TürküOla, 1976 *Wonderful, 1986
==Books== *{{Cite book |last= Taşlıova |first=Şeref |authormask= |authorlink= |firstn= |lastn= |authorn-link= |editor= |editorn-last= |editorn-first= |editor-link= |editorn-link= |others= |title=Gönül deryası |trans-title=The Heart Garden |url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |origyear= |year=1990 |publisher=Kültür Bakanlığı Halk Kültürünü Araştırma Dairesi |location=Ankara |language=Turkish |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |bibcode= |id= |page= |pages=81 |nopp= |chapter= |trans-chapter=|chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp= }}
==Notes== <references/>
